p.seg: In conduct there is such a thing as being reliably excellent;
in office-holding there is no such thing as reliably meeting with success.
Whether a person is excellent or not
is a matter of natural talent;
whether a person meets with success or not
is a matter of the right time.
If one's talents are of a high order and one's actions are pure,
then it cannot be guaranteed that one will necessarily end up in a distinguished position;
if one's abilities are slight and one's conduct is morally unclean,
then it cannot be guaranteed that one will necessarily end up in a low position.
Someone may have elevated talents and pure behaviour,
but if he does not encounter the right opportunities,
he will be held back and remain at a low level;
if one has slight abilities and impure behaviour
but meets the right opportunities
he will be placed above the crowd.
Each generation has its own way of selecting candidates for office,
and each candidate for office has his own way of advancing in office..
Advancing depends on meeting the right opportinities;
failing to advance is because one does not meet the right opportunities.
If one occupies a venerated position or a distinguished office,
that does not necessarily mean that one is talented/worthy:
it is a matter of being in the right place at the right time;
if one's rank is low and one is in a low position,
that does not necessarily mean one is stupid:
it is a matter of not having met the right opportunities.
And so, as to meeting the right opportunities,
some holding onto their impure behaviour,
would find honour in the court of a Jié;
as to not meeting the right opportunities,
some maintaining their pure behaviour
would find themselves in a lowly position at the court of a Yáo.
The reasons why one is or is not meeting the right opportunities
are by no means the same in each case:
In some cases, normally worthy men come to aid the wicked,
in other cases, men of great talent follow the path of men of slight talent;
in still other cases, men who possess great talent differ in the purity of their ways;
in still other cases, men devoid of moral standards get by on their skills;
in still other cases, men devoid of skills or abilities gain favour on the strength of their good looks.
Wǔ Yú2n and Bó Xǐ2
both served Fū Chaī.
Bó Xǐ2 was a respected political heavyweight,
and Wú Yún was executed.
this is a case where men differing in conduct still served the same lord.
Sometimes the conduct is the same, but the ruler different
and there is also the possibility of either meeting or not meeting right opportunity.
Such was the case for Yī Yín and Jī Zí.
Yī Yǐn and Jī Zǐ possessed the same talent,
but Yī Yín became prime minister.
and Jī Zǐ a slave.
This was because Yī Yǐn happened to meet Tāng the Successful,
and Jī Zǐ happened to meet Zhòu of the Shāng dynasty.
Now if, as a talented person one serves a talented ruler,
and the ruler wishes to practise good government
and if the minister supports him with his talents,
and their choices in action coincide,
then it is only to be expected that he meets with success;
if, as a talented person one serves a bad ruler
and the ruler does not wish to practise good government,
and if as a minister one aids him through loyal behaviour,
and their conduct and aspirations are in conflict with each other,
it is surely only to be expected that he does not meet with success.
Sometimes as a superbly distinguished minister
one comes across a ruler wishing to conduct proper government
but in the end somehow does not meet success.
Such was the case of Confucius and Mencius.
Confucius was short of provisions between Chén and Cài,
Mencius got into trouble in Qí and Wèi.
It was not that the rulers did not employ qualified persons;
it was rather that their talents were of a low order and their understanding shallow,
and that they thus were unable to employ men of great talent.
Now anyone able to steer a Jì Lù steed
must be a Wáng Liáng.
Anyone able to use an Yǔ, a Jì or a Gāo Yáo as minister
must be a Yáo or a Shùn.
A hand able to control a horse that runs a hundred lǐ a day
to try controlling the feet of a horse capable of running a thousand lǐ a day
is sure to suffer disasters such as that of broken yokes.
If someone with a talent sufficient for handling fill-in ministers
uses this to keep under control the wisdom of great ministers
then he is bound to encounter emergencies that will cause his mind to go blank.
Thus when perfect proposals are rejected
and men of excellence is repudiated
this is not because rulers hate men of excellence,
or because they have no taste for perfect proposals.
The point is that men of excellence aim high
and perfect proposals are hard to put into practice.
Now, when a person of great talent seeks employment with a person of small talent,
then the person of small talent will not be able to accept this,
and not meeting with success is only to be expected.
Sometimes when as a minister of great talent,
meets a ruler of great talent,
it is only then that the possibility arises both for meeting and not meeting with success.
Shùn and Xǔ Yóu, Tài Gōng and Bó Yí2 are cases in point.
Shùn and Xǔ Yóu were both sages,
both were born in the age of Táng rule,
and both came face to face with Yáo.
Shùn continued the imperial line,
whereas Xǔ Yóu went to the mountain forests.
Tài Gōng and Bó Yi were both worthies,
rose together in the kingdom of Zhōu,
and both had audiences with King Wú3.
Tài Gōng was enfeoffed,
while Bó Yì starved to death.
As to men of excellence, their way was the same, their aspirations convergent, and their choices were along the same lines,
but the actions of Yú Shùn and Tài Gōng were matching,
and the conduct of Xú Yóu and Bó Yì was at odds with each other,
they were not born in the proper age,
and did not emerge at the proper time.
Their way may have been the same
but within this sameness there was a difference;
their aspirations may have converged,
but within this convergence there was divergence.
Why is this?
Ways may be subtle or coarse
aspirations may be pure or impure.
Xǔ Yóu
was an assistant to an August One,
but he was born at a time of mere emperors;
Bó Yì
was an aide to an Emperor,
but he emerged in an age of mere kings.
Both followed high standards of morality
and both manifested goodness.
When the rulers practised their high standards of morality,
then if they were less than pure, such men would not stay with him.
When the rulers practised goodness,
then if they were not high-minded enough, such men would not remain with him.
That is why [these two ministers] did not meet with the right opportunities.
Actually, Yáo was less than spotless, and Shùn had dirty hands,
King Wǔ, in his punishments, was cruel;
Tài Gōng, in his punitive expeditions, was violent.
They were equally tainted and crude.
But the measures they took were well-balanced,
and that is why they count as having met with their right opportunities.
Thus when Shùn governed the world,
Gāo Yáo assisted him in his administration,
whereas Běirén Wúduò hid himself completely and did not show himself;
When Yǔ governed the world,
Bó Yì aided him in his rule,
whereas Bó Chéng Zǐgāo, having discarded his office, turned to tilling the fields.
It is not that the talents of Gāo Yáo surpassed those of Wúduò
or that the abilities of Bó Yì exceeded those of Zǐgāo,
but Gāo Yáo and Bó Yì advanced in service,
while Wǔduò and Zǐgāo withdrew into obscurity.
In the cases where they advanced in service, it was because their actions fitted [those of the rulers],
in the cases where they withdrew into obscurity, it was because their conduct differed [from that of the rulers].
In the cases where they withdrew into obscurity, their circumstances were not the same.
They personally may have been of low status,
they had no wish to advance.
When rulers of men do not feel any need for their proposals
and go on to reject them
(they do not regret this by themselves):
this is just a case of the two lacking mutual admiration.
The fact that Shāng Yǎng gave advice to Duke Xiào of Qín three times,
and the first two pieces of advice were not listened to,
but the last was accepted,
was because the first two pieces
presented a line of argument suitable for emperors or kings,
whereas the last one
presented arguments for those aspiring hegemon.
Now [1], when one maintains line of argument suitable for emperors or kings
and presents these as advice to a ruler who is bent on becoming a hegemon,
then even the best advice will be pushed aside;
but when one switches to advice about becoming a hegemon
then even the crudest advice will be accepted.
Why is this?
This was because the best advice happened to involve what Duke Xiào did not want to have;
and the crude advice encountered what Duke Xiào wished to put into practice.
Thus, persuasive advice does not depend on its quality ,
it depends on the approval of the person being advised;
Convincing talent does not depend on worthiness as such,
it depends on whether the person one serves appreciates one.
The rhetoric of the groom was without professional method,
but the country folk liked them;
Zǐ Gòng's rhetoric was full of meaning,
but the country folk would have none of it.
A piper produced an excellent tune
but since the king of Yùe did not find pleasure in these
he changed this into an uncivilised tune
and the king was greatly pleased.
Thus, in the case where one produces something good for a prince who does not wish to get good things,
what one produces may be excellent, but it will not be loved.
and in the case where one produces something worthless for a ruler who happens to care for worthless things,
what one produces may be worthless, but it will not be disliked.
This is congruence through parochial skills.
If one achieves such congruence then one will meet with the right opportunities
and if one does not then one will not meet with the right opportunities.
Some had no skills,
recklessly they managed to conform to their superiors' ambitions through their cunning,
and nonetheless such people had what it takes to meet with the right opportunities.
The minister who stole the hair-pin,
and the retainers who crowed like cocks are cases in point.
The minister who stole the hair-pin
became intimate with Zǐ Fǎn,
the retainers who crowed like cocks
gained favour with the lord of Mèngcháng.
Zǐ Fǎn liked the thieving minister,
Mèngcháng was fond of the retainers who faked the cock-crows.
Because they had some use to their rulers,
the rulers relied upon them;
it is only to be expected that they met with the right opportunities.
Some people may have made no contribution and offered no advantages,
but they were liked by their rulers.
Jí Rú and Dèng Tōng were cases in point.
Jí Rú was favoured by emperor Xìao Hùi,
and Dèng Tōng was loved by Xiào Wén.
These men did not even have the least trace of talent
or the slightest abilities,
It just so happened that because they cut a fine figure and were of delicate build,
their skin was captivating and their appearance was attractive.
Now a handsome looks
are what people are fond of,
and their actual success was certainly to be expected.
It may happen that some people with ugly faces and repulsive looks,
were thought to be attractive by their rulers.
Mó Mǔ and Wú Yán were cases in point.
Mó Mǔ gained advancement under Húang Dì,
and Wú Yán was accepted as a consort by the king of Qí.
Thus whether someone does or does not have the relevant talents may be ascertained beforehand
but when it comes to meeting the right opportunities it is hard to make effective plans ahead of time.
Why?
What a ruler likes or dislikes is not governed by any constant principle
and when it comes to what a subject offers up there is no telling beforehand;
What happens to match the ruler's fancies will count as right
and what happens to be acceptable counts as superior.
Those who advance in rank are not necessarily talented
and those who are held back are not necessarily bereft of talent.
If one is in congruence with the ruler and wins his favour one will get to be promoted
and if one fails to win the ruler's favour one will lose out.
Current opinion has it:
"A man of talent is able to succeed,
and when he does not succeed it is surely his own fault.
If throughout one's live, not placing their hopes in others, one aims for the ruler's thoughts
if one carefully observes the inner workings of the government,
if one attunes one's abilities so as to determine one's advice,
if one keeps a close eye on opportunities,
and if one is able to offer up things that are of help and assistance to the ruler
then how can one fail to succeed?
But nowadays things are different:
people develop profitless abilities
and they offer pointless advice.
When it is summer they offer a stove,
and when it is winter they submit a fan.
They perform services which are not wanted
and they offer up talk that no one wants to hear.
If they do not meet disaster that is a matter of luck!
What lasting good fortune can come from this?
offering one's abilities involves envisaged benefit
offering advice involves envisaged help.
This is what everyone understands."
Some people win a good fortune by doing something that is of no help
and some are accused of crimes because they did something useful.
Moreover, by the way, in summer a stove may be used to dry moisture,
in winter a fan to fan the fire.
One can successfully place one's hopes in people generally,
but a ruler cannot be predicted successfully.
Advice may be changed around,
but one's abilities cannot be exchanged for new ones.
When the ruler of one's time is fond of literature
then if one devotes oneself to literature one will meet the right opportunity [in him].
But when the ruler of one's time is fond of the military arts,
then the very same person would fail.
If a ruler is fond of rhetoric
then if one is a good talker one will succeed
But when the ruler is not fond of rhetoric
the very same man would not meet with the right opportunity.
A ruler of literary inclinations will not be fond of war;
A ruler of military inclinations will not be fond of literature.
A ruler who is inclined towards rhetoric will not be prone to activism.
An activist ruler will not be fond of arguments.
The literary arts and public speech
can still be practiced within reasonable time,
but proper behaviour and abilities
cannot be perfected at one go.
If in learning something one does not practise it persistently
one does not havew what it takes to make one's name illustrious.
And if one's name is not basically well-known
one does not have what it takes to hit it off with a ruler.
In a hurried career
with a reputation just made
one hasn't invested enough time and energy.
And since one has not been heard of ahead of time,
then how can one predict precisely the ruler's thought and offer advice accordingly,
and thus to promote one's person and to deploy the relevant abilities?
In ancient times, among the people of Zhōu, there was somebody who, in his official career, several times failed to meet his right opportunity,
he was old and white-haired,
and stood crying on the road-side.
Someone asked him:
"Why are you crying?"
He replied:
"In public office I have repeatedly failed to meet the right opportunities;
I am distressed that I have grown old and missed my time,
That is why I am crying."
The other man said :
"In your official career how come that you did not meet the right opportunity even once?"
He answered:
"When I was young,
In my studies I devoted myself to letters.
Only after I had achieved some success in my literary studies
did I begin to think of taking an office,
but at that time the ruler was prone to using old men.
When the ruler who used old men had died
his successor went on to employ men of a military bent
and I turned to the military arts.
But when I had begun to get somewhere with the military disciplines
the ruler with a military bent also died.
When the ruler, still a minor, was first established
he liked to employ young men,
but meanwhile I had become old.
That is why I never once met the right opportunity."
Gaining official employment is a matter of opportunities,
it is not something that one can get simply by seeking it.
Now, even if one places one's hopes in public opinion or anticipates the ruler's thoughts
then still success may elude one.
How much more true is this for those who have the highest standards and exquisite aspirations,
who are not moved by profit,
who are of stable character and whose substance is solidly established,
and who are therefore never even looked at by the ruler!
Moreover, when it comes to meeting the right opportunities,
one's abilities cannot be set up in advance,
and one's advice cannot be prepared beforehand.
By accident, one may meet the ruler's pleasure,
and thus may fall in with his ideas.
and then that is called meeting with right opportunities.
If one anticipates the ruler's opinion and attunes one's advice to him
and thus obtains high status;
The word for such a case is 'careful estimation'
and it is not termed 'meeting with the right opportunity'.
In spring one sows the seeds and the grain grows,
in autumn one cuts it and the grain is harvested.
if having taken the initiative for a project and bringing it to completion,
these cases are not called 'meeting with the right opportunity'.
If without having sought them things arrive of themselves,
if without one having initiated projects they are realised of themselves,
then such cases to count as meeting with the right opportunity.
It is like picking up things lost on the road,
or taking up things thrown away in the countryside,
or like Heaven giving one something, the earth making something grow,
or ghosts helping one, or spirits aiding one.
The spirit of Qín Xī indirectly brought (Bǎilǐ Xí) good fortune.
and the ghost of Bào Shū promoted a man through silence (Guǎn Zhòng).
Episodes of this kind
are indeed examples par excellence of meeting the right opportunity.
Now the vulgar people of today cannot settle on a theory of meeting or not meeting the right opportunity
When others happen to meet the right opportunity they go on to praise them
and on the basis of someone not meeting with the right opportunity they go on to criticise him.
Such a case shoes that basing oneself on visible evidence and observable objective fact
one cannot measure properly moral conduct and one cannot investigate effectively abilities.
In general, officials in their career may be hampered and checked,
their conduct may be seriously flawed and quite imperfect,
their offences may be allowed to accumulate and not be removed,
and their public recognition may remain obscure and not distinguished
It was by no means that their talent was inferior
that their actions were inconsistent,
that their intelligence was obfuscated,
or that their strategies were benighted.
They just met external distasters beyond their control
and these inhibited and harmed them.
This is not only true of the actions of men.
Quite generally, things are all like that.
Living and moving things ,
all of them have to suffer misfortunes.
Such harm come from sources outside their control
it does not come from within.
Now if one does not get to the bottom of what harm arises from
and just attributes responsibility for harm to the sufferers of harm
then one's intelligence is obfuscated
and one is in the dark with respect to the underlying principles of things.
The (plant-)creatures of this world are born in spring
and men will take care of them.
But when they are ripe in autumn
then men will certainly have no way of taking good care of them (since their life-span is nearing its end).
If for some reason oxen or horses trample on their roots
or if knives or sickles cut off the stems,
then what is born is not fostered up
and they will not ripen in autumn.
The sorts of plant-creatures that do not develop fully
are exposed to harm and are not successful,
and thus they do not get to reproduce.
When rice has been touched by rats ,
it is thrown away and not eaten.
The taste of rice that has been thrown away
is the very same as that of unpolluted rice.
One considers the rats have ruined the rice
and throws the rice away, refusing to eat it.
The misfortunes that befall the gentleman
are the same sort of case as that of the plants not taken care of and the rice left uneaten.
All these disasters come from the outside
so they are to be looked upon as misfortunes.
(Just) by cultivating oneself and regulating one's conduct,
one cannot attract good fortune,
and just through trembling fear and careful precautions,
one can not avoid disaster.
The arrival of happiness and misfortune,
is a matter of good or bad luck.
Therefore it is said:
Because one gets good fortune not through one's own efforts
therefore good fortune is called good fortune;
because misfortune comes not from oneself
therefore misfortune is called misfortune.
If misfortune does not come from oneself
where does it come from?
It arises from one's native country and from the court.
There are three kinds of disastrous entanglements deriving from the native country,
and three disastrous calamites deriving from the court.
The misfortunes originate in one's native country,
and the calamites in the court.
In ancient and modern times men of tremendous talent and unimpeachable conduct have often run into this.
Which are the so-called three misfortunes and which the three calamites?
In general, in their conduct,
people are unable to pay proper attention to choosing their friends.
As for friends, when these have the same attitudes as they, they are on good generous terms with them.
But when these friends have different attitudes from them they keep them at a distance and are ungenerous.
and if they are estranged they will be full of resentment.
and they will have a negative impact on one's proper conduct.
This is the first disastrous entanglement.
The relative level of men's talents
cannot be the same for everyone.
When sèveral people move forward at the same time
those with higher talents gain glory
and those with lower talents are reduced to a rage that comes from shame.
These disgruntled people will have a negative impact on their competitors' behaviour.
That is the second kind of disastrous entanglement.
When men interact with each other
they cannot always be on cheerfully friendly terms.
When one is on cheerfully friendly terms one gets close to each other
when one feels angry one gets alienated.
When one is alienated one feels resentment
and then people will have a negative impact on one's conduct.
That is the third kind of disastrous entanglement.
Since offices are few, and candidates many,
officials will compete for promotion
and those who are promoted will compete for (the best) offices.
When they meet high level officials they will malign each other
and they will pile lies upon lies.
These high level officials have no clear insight into things
and so they accept such maligning pronouncements.
Such is the first calamity.
Leaders and executive officials have different propensities,
pure and impure officials have different forms of behaviour.
The morally immaculate officials pile on their elegant declarations
and give their pure words.
The morally impure officials harbour rancours,
and by degrees try to find the fault with their rivals,
and on the basis of the slightest slander
they are accused of crimes and punished.
That is the second disaster.
A leader may have a predilection for the person of an aide.
and believed their words .
Then even if that aide does not show pure conduct
they are bound to be promoted skipping the ranks.
On the contrary when someone does not fit their ideals
the leader will malign them beyond all measure.
Pure and straightforward officials,
if they act obstreporously and strain to realise their aspirations,
then they will be hated,
and they will be maligned by the leader.
That is the third kind of damage.
Now even before they advance in office
they personally suffer these three disastrous entanglements;
and having gained official appointment
they personally suffer these disasters.
Even Confucius and Mòzǐ were unable to escape from this,
and Yán Huí as well as Zēng Shēn were unable to remain unharmed.
When one has taken the initiative for a hundred actions
and did in thousand things,
envious persons
would rise around them like clouds.
Thorns and prickles would prick them and stick to their bodies and faces.
Creatures like bees and scorpions
will nibble at and sting men of decent behaviour.
There certainly are not only six of these disasters.
These six may be very obvious indeed,
but society seems never to have noticed them.
Now if one does not investigate how freeman suffer three disastrous entanglements as a result of their conduct
and how officials suffer three disasters,
then one will call those who go unscathed they will call undefiled
and those who have been calumniated they will call dishonoured;
Those who advance in their career they will call excellent,
and those who are dismissed from office they will call bad.
If someone goes unscathed and advances in office,
that is just a matter of good luck;
but they go ahead and praise him;
and if someone is slandered and dismissed from office,
that may be just a matter of not hitting it right,
but such people will go head and speak ill of him.
If one takes these kinds of attitudes
this is sure to be because one does not understand the three disastrous entanglements and the three disasters.
and they do not understand that those who suffer these disastrous entanglements and disasters may show talented and pure behaviour.
If one strikes with clay at mud
or one speckles black silk with black,
who will know what is happening?
Purity seems to be exposed to dust
whiteness takes in dirt.
What the giant flies will sully
is always the white silk.
One who is standing on a highest is in danger,
and those living in prosperity suffer losses.
The kinds of things that have fallen down ,
usually were in precipitous places.
Qū Píng was a man of purity,
but all the dogs in the country barked at him.
Dogs barked at what appeas strange to them.
Criticising remarkable men and being suspicious of heroes
certainly shows a mediocre attitude.
A remarkable person is held responsible because of his extraordinary ability
will attract the sound of the barking pack of dogs.
Such being the case,
why should one go on to encourage slaves to follow incompetent people (with attitudes like that)?
The incompetent and the slavish
are not the men who should be encouraged.
Should then one adapt to the world and to keep one's person hale and whole in order to avoid slander?
Those who match with the vulgar crowd and keep their persons hale and whole
are hypocrites.
Those hypocrites
affect impeccable, flawless behaviour
and there is nothing one can blame them for
there is nothing one might attack them sharply for.
But those were at the same time the men who were blamed by Confucius
and condemned by Mencius.
Those who excelled through talent and attractiveness in ancient time,
could not safeguard themselves.
Thus those who followed nature in their actions to prepare for the disastrous calamities
were in actual fact the talented and morally pure people.
By carrying the slander which leads to diastrous calamities to extremes
the truth about their talent and moral purity became manifest.
If one has established manifest evidence of one's talent and moral purity
how can there fail to arise the defilement of slander?
The players wish they could break the fingers of Bó Yá,
and the charioteers wish they could have crushed the hands of Wáng Liáng.
Why?
Because they were all craving for the fame of exceptional skill ,
and resented that other were better than they.
Thus the girl of Wèi was a great beauty,
but Zhèng Xiù cut her nose off.
Cháo Wú was loyal and honest,
but Wú Jì expelled him.
If someone has an ingratiating appearance he will increasinly arouse envy
and a sycophantic person will call up many glib-toungued people around him.
Therefore, one does not sprinkle dust in wet halls,
and for a humble cottage one does not build an (elaborate) wind-breaker.
Plants shaken by the wind cannot be made to grop properly,
and banks against which the water dashes to do get to be craggy and sharp.
Things being like this,
then the events in Yǒu Lǐ, Chén and Cài may be properly understood,
and the drowning oneself in the Yangtse, and the jumping into the Yellow River may also be understood.
If someone uses surpassing talent in order to curry favour with the vulgar crowd,
and if one strives to safeguard on's reputation for efficiency in the eyes of the leader,
and one then does not meet with the disaster that befell Dèng Xì ,
and does not bring upon oneself the punishment that befell Zǐ Xù,
then one has been really lucky.
People did not assault the dead body of Mèng Bēn,
because he had breathed his last.
nor do they throw water on a hundred bushels of burnt out embers,
because the glow of the fire is extinguished.
If one acts to show off one's intelligence
and shows off the light of one's glory to the entire world,
or if dedicating oneself to higher aspirations one is arrogant to one's peers,
and stands towering above all the common folk,
then one will certainly always be slandered or envied by educated people.
For one's right-mindedness one incurs disastrous entanglements due to the vulgar crowd.
One seeks to be of use, but on the contrary one loses out.
Perhaps it was this that Confucius was worried about
and what Mencius was full of sorrow about.
Those possessed of great virtue attract calumnies ,
and those who are (mere) freemen will indulge in dirty rhetoric (against them).
To avert the calamity araising from talk behind one's back through a brilliant reputation
and try to avoid the problems of a highly precarious situation,
that is far indeed from being feasible.
The defamation of Zāng Cāng
has not yet died out,
and the calumny of Gōng Bó Liáo
has not yet gone out.
Ant-hills are made into mountains ,
and rivulets into rivers and streams.
According to this,
if the king of Wèi mistaking that there is tiger in the city,
and the mother of Zēng Zǐ throwing away the shuttle,
is not enough to be regarded as strange,
then jade changing into stone,
and a pearl changing into a shingle,
is also not enough to be marvelled at.
Why?
The limited understanding of a completely obfuscated mind brings this about.
What King Wén considered as mere dung and soil,
was exactly what Èlái (senior minister to Tyrant Zhòu) considered as precious metal and jade.
It was not that Zhòu hated sageliness and was fond of wickedness.
His intellect was confused and beclouded.
If one is confused and beclouded and unable to get clear about things,
then even Wēizǐ leaving his office ten times
or Bǐ Gān cutting himself five times.
would not be something to be really worried about.
Thus when the three "Overseers" (younger brothers appointed by the Duke of Zhōu) slandered the sage,
he fled to Chǔ.
When the stepmother maligned the filial son
Bó Qí was banished and went into exile.
At that time, during the period of the Zhōu, who was not confused?
Afterwards the Chīxiāo song was made and the Shǔlí song became the rage.
Those who sang about these things
were saddened by the events.

Moreover, changes in thingsfollowing the qi is just like
responses to political rule.

alter their forms many times31

[the only aspects which] change

He was a bully, with no manners.

share the empire's rule with Gāozǔ.
Chén Píng, being poor, was short of food, but
his demeanor and form were fine
so many people remarked on it with surprise.
"What did Chén Píng eat to become so fat?"
When Hán Xìng was read by the Duke of Téng, as in a mirror,
he escaped the executioner's block .
This was likewise because there was something special in his countenance.
A fleshy and fine face
is also a good sign.
Gā1ozǔ had a high nose, a dragon face, and a luxuriant beard ;
his left leg had seventy-two moles.
Old man Lǚ in Shànfǔ was good at physiognomy.
When he saw Gāozǔ's appearance,
he thought it remarkable,
so he gave his daughter in marriage to Gāozǔ.
This was [later] Empress Lǚ,
who then gave birth to the Filial Emperor Huì,
and the Princess Yuán of Lǔ.70
When Gāozǔ held the post of village head in Sìshàng,
he was on the point of asking leave to (P.113)return to his farm,
so that he might live with Empress Lǚ and their two children, when
an old man passed by,
and asked for a drink.
Thereupon he read Empress Lǚ's physiognomy,
"Madam,
you will be one of the great of the world. "
Empress Lǚ had him look at her two children, and
when he examined [the future] Emperor Huì, he said:
"This young man is the reason you will be honored ."
And then he read Princess Yuán's face and form and
said:
"All are noble."
After the old man left,
Gāozǔ came back from his stint abroad,
and Empress Lǚ told this to Gāozu;
and so Gāozǔ ran after the old man,
and stopped him, asking him to read his own fortune.
The old man said:
"The lady and children which I read awhile ago resemble you,
your physiognomy is too noble to put into words."
Afterwards Gāozǔ gained the empire,
as the old man had foretold.
Generalizing from this, we find that
members of a single house
all had the phsyiognomy of the wealthy and high-ranked.
Belonging to a same class of beings, endowed with the same qi,
their forms and physiognomies must naturally resemble one another's71.
But those of different qi who belong to different classes may
also encounter one another.
A man destined for wealth and rank
will marry a woman destined for the same.
And a woman destined for wealth and rank will get a man destined for the same.
Now, when the physiognomies of the two vary, if the people meet
a sudden death ensues.
Or if the time is out of joint,
one party will have the misfortune to (P.114)die prematurely.
When Wáng Mǎng's aunt, Zhèngjūn, was betrothed to others,
the bridegroom suddenly died
when the time came to be married.
Twice this happened
before she was given to King of Zhào,
but King of Zhào had not yet married her
when he also died.
Nángōng Dàyǒu of Qīnghé
was a man who enjoyed good relations with Zhìjūn, Zhèngjūn's father.
When they met, he divined her fate:
"She will be honored as mother to the empire."
At that time,
Emperor Xuān was on the throne,
and [the future] Emperor Yuán was crown prince.
Zhìjūn used the good offices of the
Commander of Wèi commandery to have her presented to the crown prince.
The crown prince favored her with his presence,
and she gave birth to a son named Jūnshàng.
When Emperor Xuān died,
the crown prince ascended the throne,
Zhèngjūn became empress,
and her son Jūnshàng was made crown prince.
Upon Emperor Yuán's death,
Jūnshàng ascended the throne.
He it was who was Emperor Chéng;
Zhèngjūn became empress dowager;
finally she had become Mother to the empire.
Now Zhèngjūn's physiognomy was that of a person who would become Mother to the empire,
but neither her two former fiancs nor King of Zhào
had the physiognomy proper to someone who is Father to the empire.
For that reason, she did not marry the two men, and they, along with
King of Zhào, died.
This is a case of the two men and the King of Zhao
lacking the destiny of emperors,
And so it was right that Zhèngjūn did not
bear the signs that her fortune would coincide with any of the three other families.
When Chancellor Huáng Cìgōng was
border warden in Yángxià, he once
travelled in the same carriage with a (P.115)man who was good at physiognomy.
When they saw a woman seventeen or eighteen years of age,
the fortune-teller pointed to her and said:
" This woman will be wealthy and honoured; she
will become a vassal lord's wife."
Cìgōng stopped the carriage,
and looked her over carefully.
The physiognomer said:
"If this woman does become wealthy and honoured,
I'll throw away my divination books."
Cìgōng made inquiries
and it turned out she was a daughter (p.37)of a shaman in the neighbourhood.
Forthwith he married her
and later
Cìgōng really did become very wealthy and honoured,
as he reached in office the rank of Chancellor, and he
was enfeoffed as a noble.
Since Cìgōng was destined to be for wealth and rank,
the woman had to marry him, and
so it came about that they met,
with the result that both became wealth and honoured.
If Cìgōng had been destined to be humble,
he would not have been able to get the woman for his wife;
And if it had not been the right time for them to marry,
then he would have encountered the same calamity as the two fiances and the King of Zhào.
Only if the whole family is destined for wealth and rank will they all
be able to do what brings them wealth and honor.
But if the bone structure and physical form have something incongruent,
then they will certainly be separated from each other and die;
they will not be able to enjoy great blessings for a long time.
Consequently, in families destined for wealth and rank, [even]
the servants and slaves they employ,
the cattle and horses they raise,
must vary from the ordinary ones for sure.
The servants and slaves have the physiognomies of those who will not die easily;
the cattle and horses have apredisposition to reproduce over and over again.
Should they cultivate the land,
their grain quickly ripens.
And should they become merchants,
their merchandise is good and quickly sold.
And so it is that those who know fate
can discern the wealthy and honoured from the poor and humble,
can spy out the poor and humble from the wealthy and honoured.
By inspecting the bone structure
and observing the veins in the skin,
they see people's natures and fates,
which never do not coincide.
Zhào Jiǎnzǐ bade Gūbù Zǐqīng read his sons' physiognomies.
None was auspicious
until he came to Wúxù, the son of the Di slave-girlì,
whom he considered to be noble.
Wúxù was the most worthy,
and he also had a noble physiognomy.
Later Jiǎnzǐ deposed his heir and established Wúxù ,
so that he finally became a vassal (P.116)lord.
This was Xiāngzǐ.
The physiognomer read Qíng Bù's physiognomy [which said]
he would be tortured first before he became king.
Later, he was punished, as expected, and then he was installed.
Zhèng Jì, WèiQīng's father,
had sex with a miss Wei, who was a maid to the Princess Yángxìn,
and she gave birth to Wèi Qīng.
When Wèi Qīng was in service at Jiànzhāng palace,71
a convict who had been tortured physiognomized him.
He said,
"You will be honored as a vassal lord."
Wèi Qīng replied:
" The way of a slave is such that I
think it enough not to be whipped and reviled;
How would I dare to dream of become a lord?"
But later on, Wèi Qīng became an army officer, and
he had merit in battle, time after time.
So he skipped ranks in his promotions
and ended up as a generalissimo,
at which point he was enfeoffed as marquis over ten thousand families.
When Zhōu Yàfū had not been enfeoffed,
Woman Xǔ physiognomized him,
and said:
"In three years you will becomemarquis, and
after eight years as marquis, you will (P.117)become general and minister,

You will be extremely honoured,
without peer among the emperor's subjects.

Yàfū replied with a laugh:
" My elder brother has already taken over the title of marquis, and
if the father dies, his son succeeds.
Why do you say that I will become a marquis?
And granted that this is so, once ennobled,
as you have said,
how do you account for my death by starvation?
Please show me the signs."
Woman Fù pointed to his mouth,
where a perpendicular line entered,
and said:
"This is the mark of death by starvation."
Three years passed,
and his elder brother Shèngzhī, the Marquis of Jìang, committed a crime.71
Emperor Wén chose the most worthy of the sons of the marquises of Jìang.
Yàfū was proposed,
and then was installed as Marquis of Tiāo,
to succeed the Marquis of Jìang.
In the sixth year of Emperor Wén's second reign period [158 BC],71
the Xiōngnú invaded,
and Zhou Yàfū was appointed general.
During Emperor Jǐing's reign,
Yàfū became prime minister;
later on he retired on account of illness.
His son on Yafu's behalf
bought five hundred shields and suits of armour from the imperial workshop for the palace,
thinking to use it for Yàfū's funeral.
The workmen he chose thought that it very hard work
and he did not give them any tips.
The men knew that he had illegally bought official government items,71
so they reported the son, in their anger, to the throne.
EmperorJing dispatched clerks to conduct an investigation,
and because Yafu did not eat for five days,
he spat blood and died.
Just at that point Dèng Tōng enjoyed the favors of Emperor Wén,
so he was ranked above the ministers.
Dèng was given hundreds of millions in cash,
and his person was held to be the equal of theemperor's.
A physiognomer, reading his fortune, said:
"You are doomed to be poor and (P.118)miserable, and to die of starvation."
After Emperor Wén died,
Emperor Jǐng succeeded,
and Dèng Tōng was charged with the crime of illegal coining.
Emperor Jǐng held an inquiry,
and Dèng Tōng fled.
[After that] he lived in another's home, where he died,
without a single coin to his name.
When Senior Tutor Hán was a student,
he lent a physiognomer fifty cash,
and they went together into the Biyong grounds.
The physiognomer figured out who among those at the Biyong would be be noble.
He pointed at Ní Kuān:
"This student is bound to be noble;
he will rise in rank to be one of the three senior ministers."
Scholar Hán sent him on his way
then he handed a piece of bamboo with his name on it to Ní Kuān.73
They became inseparable friends,
and he paid him every honor.
Scholar Han moved his house to follow Ní Kuān,
and he bestowed every favour and mark of condecenscion upon him.
Ni Kuān once had a serious illness,
Scholar Hán looked after him as if hewere his servant.
His kindness toward Ní Kuān was deeper than toward his kin.
Later on, he became famous all over the empire, and when
Ní Kuān attained the rank of State Counsellor,
his subordinates in the commanderies and kingdoms recommended him,
and ended up being Senior Tutor.
Now, the convict who had been tortured and Woman Xu, and
the physiognomers with Deng Tong and Ni Kuan as well,
can be said to be experts in knowing fate.
Therefore, the experts who know fate
can see the signs on the body that portend a person's fate;
they can discern the marks of wealth and honor, poverty and low rank.
It is just like looking at plates --
one knows for whom they are designed.
Good vessels are always for use by the higher-ranked,
and the inferior ones are for those low in rank.
Wine cups and tripods are not found in a side room,
and gourds and calabashes are not found in the principal hall.
That much is clear, certainly.
One who has the bones for wealth and rank
does not suffer the hardship of being poor and humble;
and one who has the look of a poor and humble man
does not come upon the pleasures of wealth and rank,
so this, too, is also like this.
Containers
may hold a peck or a picul,
just as people's ranks have a range of high and low.
If the containers are overfilled,
the contents spill out and are discarded.
And if men surpass the proper rank,
they die.
Those who analyze destiny compare it to containers.
If one uses the method of searching the bones,
then it is certain that destiny resides in the physical form.
And not only do wealth and honor, poverty and low rank, depend on the bodily frame,
but conduct also, whether good or bad, leaves its marks.
Honor and low rank, poverty and riches
are a matter of fate;
conduct, good and bad,
is a matter of human nature.
Not only does destiny have its marks in the bones, but
nature also leaves its marks in the bones.
[If] one only knows that destiny leaves clear marks, but
does not understand that human nature leaves its marks,
this to see the external signs of destiny,
but not the clear proofs of human nature.
When Fan4 Lǐ left Yuè, from Qí
he sent off a letter to a counsellor (P.120)Zhòng, saying:
"When the birds in flight are all gone,
the good bow is put away;
when the cunning hare has died,
the hunting dog goes in the pot.
The King of Yuè has a long neck and a bird's beak.
One can share hardship with him,
but not the pleasures that come from glory.
Why not leave from him?"
The counsellor Zhóng could not find it within himself to leave.
pretending to be ill, he did not attend court.
He was presented with a sword [with which to kill himself] and so he died.
Wèi Liǎo, a native of Dàliáng,
in a speech to Qín Shihuáng
gave a plan to unify the empire.
75 The First Emperor accepted his proposal,
and treated him with the courtesies due an equal,
allowing him to wear the same clothes and eat the same foods as he had.
Wèi Liǎo said:
"The king of Qín
has a high nose, elongated eyes,
the chest of a vulture and the voice of a jackal.
He is little, if any, sense of obligation.
He has the look of a tiger and the heart of a wolf.
When he lived in straitened circumstances, he submitted to others easily,
but once he achieves his aspirations, he also despises others.
I am but a commoner,
but when he sees me,
he always treats me with great condescension.
But if the king of Qín really achieves his goal,75
the empire will surely become his slave.
One cannot have dealings with him."
And then he went away.
Thus Fan4 Lǐ and Wèi Liǎo,
seeing the unmistakeable signs of the [two kings'] nature and conduct,
used these to determine future realities.
Reality has its proofs,
just like the signs in the face and (P.121)bones.
From this we may conclude,
human nature and destiny are tied to the bodily form and bone structure -- clearly.
Judging from the records in the uncanonical texts, and
our common knowledge of the world,
we deduce that in both olden and modern times
there must be a great many cases of which we have not heard,
each having its own reality.
The vital qi endowed by Heaven
establishes the bodily forms on earth.
Looking at the forms on earth
in order to examine the destinies that rest on Heaven,
one may in every case get at that reality.
In some traditions, Confucius physiognomized Tántái Zǐyǔ77
and Táng Jǔ divined Cài Zé.
[In neither case] did they take their proofs from the patterns.
77Their failure stemmed from the fact that they did not observe
the invisible and subtle signs in the (P.122)appearance.
Some physiognomic signs are in the interior,
and some in the exterior;
some may be in the bodily,
and some in the voice.
In looking at the exterior, one may overlook the exterior.
In focusing on the body, one may ignore the voice.
When Confucius went to Zhèng,
he got separated from his disciples.
Confucius stood by himself at the east gate of Zhèng.
Some men of Zhèng said to Zigòng,
" There is a man at the east gate,
whose head resembles that of Yáo,
whose neck resembles that of Gāo Yáo,
whose shoulders resemble those of Zǐchǎn.
But from his waist downward
he is shorter by three inches than Yǔ,
and he seems like a dog that has lost its home."
When Zǐgòng reported this to Confucius,
Confucius, laughing withdelight, said:
"They didn't get the form right [when they made those extravagant compliments],
[but when they said] I was just like a stray dog,
they were right, they were right!"
Now, with the physiognomy of Confucius
the men of Zhèng failed to capture the true reality.79
They were undiscerning,
because their techniques were superficial.
Confucius failed with Zǐyǔ
and Táng Jǔ was misled with Cài Zé --
those are cases just like the Zheng men physiognomizing Confucius.
They could not see the reality behind (P.123)the surface appearance. 80
To use the appearance [only] to judge a person,
is to make the same mistake that Confucius made with respect to Zǐyǔ;
to judge another [only] by his words
is to make the same mistake as was made with Zǎiyú.
A man whose nature and destiny predispose him to wealth and rank
receives at the beginning the qi to make this so of its own.
After being raised to adulthood,
his destiny for wealth and rank will be demonstrated, for sure.
King Wén got the scarlet bird.
King Wǔ got the white fish and red crow.
When classicists discuss these,
they are of the opinion that the bird indicated King Wén's receipt of the Mandate [for rule]; and
the fish and crow, King Wu's receipt of the Mandate.
When Kings Wén and Wǔ received their predestined mandatesī from Heaven,

Heaven used the scarlet bird to mandate King Wén['s course], which
King Wén [somehow] did not receive;
Then Heaven, in a second try, used the fish and crow to mandate King Wǔ['s course].
If it is as they say,
then originally there is no predestined mandate from Heaven.
It was just that [these men] cultivated themselves and did good,
so that their good deeds became known to Heaven,
after which Heaven conferred on them the destiny to rule the empire.
And so the bird, fish and crow
represented Heaven's employing them as kings,
and [that Mandate] upheld by the kings held was used to execute [Heaven's] punishments.
If we analyze the problem based on the facts at hand,
[the classicists' theories] are not [talking about] destiny.
Destiny
is defined as what one gets in one's first endowment, that animates. í
When humans alive receive their human natures,
they then get their destinies as well.
Nature and destiny both are endowed,
and they are gotten at the very same time.
It is not that people get their natures first,
and later on they get their destinies.
How am I to make this clear?
Qì served Yáo as Commander,
and as grain officer,

When Chāng was in swaddling clothes,

King Wén's receipt of his predestined Mandate

[And that would be shown by] this Great King Gugōng's seeing it early.
But this view still has not yet got it.
King Wén, when still inside his mother's body,
had already received his destiny.
Once kings received their mandates,

The bodily form
means the bony structure in the face around the eyes and around the jaws,

From clerks with a salary of a hundred piculs on up,
to kings and vassal lords,
from Courtiers, Generals, (P.126)Counsellors, to the premier wellborn men,

could see the signs right away.
Officials may rise grade by grade,

They are predestined to honor and high rank,

A king is the most honored of the honoured,
the greatest of the great.
His animate being includes a destiny for greatness, so
in his time, his person has the special signs for honor and rank.
Gǔgōng recognized them.
That was his taking note of the portent of the four nipples.
For four nipples
are proof of the sage.
When King Wén was in his mother's body,

So how could it possibly be true that
the four nipples grew only in adulthood

Applying the example of King Wén's nipples to King Wǔ's upward-turning eyes,
we can also know that he had already
received it [destiny] when he still a fetus.
When Dame Liú rested by the side of the great marsh,
she dreamt she encountered a god,
and consequently gave birth to Gāozǔ.
At that time Gāozǔ had already received his destiny.
When Guāngwǔ was born in the Jìyáng palace,
it was midnight, and there was no fire,
but the room was filled with light..
A guard Sū Yǒng
said to the secretary to the Director of
Merit, Chōng Lán,
"This is an auspicious event.
Do not say anything more about it. "
At that time Guāngwǔ had already received his destiny.
If we only say it was Kings Wen and Wu
who got the scarlet bird, fish and crow before they received the Mandate,
this is wrong.
High Heaven gives its orders once,
after which a king arises.
It does not give a second decree out an another time.
Whoever gets such a destiny for wealth and rank
will rise on his own accord to become a king.
What will I use to prove it?
Say an old man in a rich family has
accumulated a thousand jin.
At birth, he has the bone structure of a man of wealth;
he does business, and his wealth piles up
until he is old, when he
becomes a rich old man.
Now a king is
the rich old man of the empire.
The destiny endowed is set in his [mother's] body,
just as birds are sexed
inside the eggshells.
When the eggs are hatched, male and (P.127)female are born.
After some days and months go by, their joints become strong.
And once they are strong, the male leads the female, without being told to.
It is not that after the males grow up
someone teaches them to act as males,

It is certainly that their qi natures are tough,

Now he who is king
is the archetypal male in the empire.
He is destined to be king,
and that destiny was set when he was in the womb,
just as wealth and rank are born in the bones,
and as the male sex of the bird is formed in the egg.ì
It is not only true for humans and birds,
but for all the myriad things.
Grass and trees grow from kernels and seeds;
they emerge from the ground as sprouts;
they grow stalks and leaves gradually,
and they become tall or short, big or small.
All have their kernels and seeds.
A king
is the acme of greatness.
A stalk of redgrass is needle-thin;
a sprout of purple boletus is like a bean. [Yet]
both serve as auspicous signs, certainly.
That a king is produced by the endowment of qi is
also a case like this.
Some may say:
"A king receives Heaven's Mandate at birth,

〞implies a commission sent [by Heaven] and accepted [by the recipient]." ì

as just like Guǎn Zhòng's taking the property.

how could the classics say "Heaven
[I say;]

Now, a great man joins his virtues with that of Heaven and Earth;

his orderliness joins that of the four seasons;

straight on his heart's impulse,
the classic therefore has talk of "before and after Heaven;87
his actions accord with Heaven's timing;
hence the passage about "not (P.130)offending and supporting Heaven."
The Analects3 says:
"How great was Yáo as sovereign!
Only Heaven is great,
and only Yáo models himself on it."
It means the true king takes heaven as model;
this implies that he does not give offense and he supports Heaven."
We deduce that the self-so nature
joins with heaven in harmony.
That, then, is what we mean by "the great mandate to King Wen."
It was King Wén's own idea
and he acted by himself.
It was not Heaven that sent the scarlet bird
to make an announcement to King Wén,
telling him that he would become king,
and only then dared to rise up.
That being the case, King Wén's scarlet bird
and King Wǔ's white fish
were not ordered by Heaven;
they were just auspicious signs of his glory.
Lucky men, in their initiatives,
turn everything to advantage.
Supporters flock to them without their being called;
and auspicious objects come without being sought.
They converge, though there has been no talk;
it seems as if someone has sent them.
When out the door, they hear whatever is lucky;
and when they turn to look back, they always see the good.
It is the way it is of itself.
When King Wén was due to arise,
the scarlet bird happened to come;
The fish leapt, and the bird flew,
and King Wǔ saw them by chance.
It was not that Heaven sent the bird and the white fish to him, but that
the lucky thingswere in motion when the sage encountered them.
When the white fish jumped into the ruler's boat,
Wáng Yáng said:
"It is sheer coincidence."
When Liú Kūn, Palace Manager,
was Governor of Hóng Nóng,
the tigers crossed the Yellow River.
Emperor Guāngwǔ called it
"sheer coincidence."
"It was not caused by something or somebody."
Thus what Wáng Yáng dubbed coincidence
and Guāngwǔ happenstance
Human dispositions and human nature
are the basis of governing men,
the source of rites and music.
Therefore if one traces out to the very end the human dispositions and human natures,
rites become the constraints for them,
and music, the way to modulate them.
Human natures may be humble, modest, and self-abnegating.
So the rites were devised to accord with what is proper;
Human dispositions include likes and and dislikes, delight and anger, sorrow and pleasure.
And so they composed music to convey proper respect.
The reason that rites are instituted
and music composed
is because of human dispositions and human natures.
When the old classical scholars
of long ago wrote essays,
each and every one of them discussed[this topic],
but not one could ascertain the truth.
Shì Shuò in the Zhòu
held that human nature includes both good and bad;
If the commendable parts of human nature
is nurtured and brought out,
then the good increases, and
if the despicable parts of human nature are nurtured and brought out,
(P.132)then the bad increases.
Since it like this, then
each human nature has yin and yang;
Doing good and bad depends upon what a person cultivates in it.
Accordingly, Shìzǐ composed a essay called "On Nurture."
Men like Fú Zǐjiàn, Qīdiāo Kāi
and Gōngsūn Nízǐ,
also discussed human nature and human disposition;
roughly the same as Shìzǐ,
they all declared that human nature includes both the commendable and the despicable.
In essays, Mencius wrote that human nature is good.
He held that the human nature is entirely good, and
that when they do evil,
it is because [outside] things have thrown them into confusion.
He claimed that humans, being born of heaven-and-earth,
are all endowed with commendable natures;
but those who make contact with the outside world in adulthood
become permissive and perverted
so that day by day they become more not-good.
If we are to follow Mencius' theory,
a human, when still a child,
would be absolutely good throughout.
Wēizǐ said:
"I once remarked that the child
was no better than the other princes."88 (P.133)
When [the evil] Zhòu was still a child,
Wēizǐ had noted his despicable nature.
As he did evil by nature, he failed to surpass ordinary men,
and when he grew up, he wreaked havoc incessantly.
Hence the remark.
When Yángshé Siwǒ was first born
Lady Shū came to have a look at him.
When she entered the hall,
she heard the sound of his wailing, 曰 ： and then she went back to her apartments, saying:
"His voice
is that of a wolf.
One with such boundless greed will recognize no kinship ties.
If not he, no one will cause the destruction of the Yángshe family."
And so she declined to see him
When he had grown up,
Qí Shèng formented rebellion,
and Sì4wǒ joined in it.
The people of the capital killed Sìwǒ,88
and the Yángshe clan was extinguished on account of this.
Zhòu's evil impulses appeared when
he was still a child; and
Sìwǒ's propensity to make trouble,
at the first sound when he was born.
When a child has just been born,
he has yet not made contact with things outside, so
who would have made him so perverse?
Dān Zhū was born in Yáo's palace,
and Shāng Jūn was born in Shun's apartments.
During the reigns of Yao and Shun,
it would have been proper to confer a title on each and every house [so good and wise were their subjects].
Those with whom thay came into contact
must certainly have been, for the most part, good.
And those at the sides of the two rulers
must certainly have been, for the most part, worthies.
Nevertheless, Dān Zhū was arrogant,
and Shāng Jūn brutal.
Both lost the right to rule, and so
down through the ages they have served as warnings [to us all].
And another thing: Mencius physiognomized men by the pupils of their eyes.
"If the heart is pure, the pupils are clear;
and if the heart is not, the pupils are dull."88
When humans are born, their pupils are always clear or dull.
The degree of clarity is endowed by Heaven,
being a matter of different qi.
It is not that eyes become clear during early childhood,
and that they change to dull after
contact with others in adulthood.
Human nature at base is self-so;
doing good or bad has its basic stuff.
Mencius's talk of human dispositions and human nature
does not quite match reality.
That being the case, his theory that human nature is good is
not entirely without foundation.
Some may be humane and some dutiful,
due to the disjunction between human nature and artful cultivation.
In deeds, whether one walks or soars
is attributable to the gap between human nature and factual knowledge.
The color of one's face may be white or black;
one's bodily form may be long or short.
This, up to old age and death,
cannot be altered,
because Heaven's nature makes it so.
Everybody recognizes with vessels made of clay
that the form and basic nature of the materials are not the same.
but nobody sees any difference in the endowments for good and bad.
A baby one year old
has no mind to contend or compete.
But after he has grown up,
he may be become infected by the desire for profit,
which will give rise to
uncontrollable desires and perverse behaviour.
Gàozǐ, a contemporary of Mencius,
whose opinion held the good and bad exist unseparated in human nature,
compared it to rushing water.
directed to the east, it will go east;
directed to the west, it will go west.
Now, water having no particular bent toward east or west
is like a man's having no particular (P.136)bent toward good or bad.
Now Gàozǐ's theory would
mean that human nature is the same as water.
If we take human nature to be like water,
then we can use water as metaphor for human nature,
This is like metal's being metal
and wood's being wood.
A man who is good takes on the good
and the bad, likewise, takes on the bad.
The heaven-sent manner one has when first endowed
has received the basic stuff, which is absolutely pure.
Therefore at birth portents may appear
and [the inherent] good and bad can be discerned.
[Human natures] where there is no division into good and bad,
which can be changed for good and ill --
these we call the average people.
Being neither [especially] good or bad,
they await instruction for character formation.
Therefore Confucius said:
"With those above average,
one can speak of higher subjects;
with those below average,
one cannot."89
Gàozi's metaphor of directed water
only applies to average people;
it does not refer to the extremely good or bad.
Confucius said:
" Human natures are similar,
but practice makes them differ." 89
Thus the human natures of average people
depend upon what they exercise in them.
Whosoever practices the good becomes good;
whosoever practices evil becomes evil.
But with the moral extremes,
they are no in the same way dependent upon practice.
Hence Confucius's assertion:
"Only the very wisest and the very most ignorant do not change."
That means that human nature's having good and bad is
such that the moral influence of the sages and worthies
cannot alter it.
Confucius is the great ancestor, as it were, of the moral way,
and the most eminent of all thinkers.
And [even] he asserts that "the very wisest and the very most ignorant do not change."
Therefore Gàozǐ's theory
has not yet got the entire truth.
Now Gaozu's theory
also is not entirely without foundation.
The Ode says:
"That good man,
what can we give him?"
The tradition says:
"The metaphor is to white silk.
dye it with indigo and it becomes blue.
dye it with vermilion and it turns red."
Now directing water one can make it go east or west, in that respect being
like dying silk, which makes it blue or (P.137)red.
Dān Zhū and Shāng Jūn
had already been drenched in the exemplary models of Yao and Shun.
But Dān Zhū remained arrogant, and Shāng Jūn brutal because
a basic stuff so extremely bad
will not accept the indigo and vermilion and so be changed.
Xúnzǐ89 had his disagreements with Mencius.
He wrote an essay entitled "Human nature is despicable,"
which supposed human nature to be bad,
and the good to be a product of artifice.
That human nature is despicable
means that people at birth all get a bad nature
and the phrase "artifice"
refers to the mature phase,
when, through their own efforts, they make themselves do good.
If we accept the theory of Xunzi,
young children are absolutely without the good.
[But] when HouJì was a child,
he sowed and planted as a game.
And when Confucius could barely walk,
he played around with the sacrificial vessels, zu and dou.
When a stone is produced, it is hard;
when an orchid blooms, it has its scent.
Being endowed with good qi, a person
will, as in maturation, go towards perfection.
And so it was that he who played withplanting
became Commander to Yao.
And he who played with vessels
became the sage-model for Zhōu.
What is endowed with a nature of orchid or stone
would then have the corresponding sign of hardness and scent.
Now, Xunzi's theory
has not quite got at the truth.
Still, the theory that human nature is despicable
likewise has some foundation.89
A baby one year old
has no idea of holding back.
Seeing some food,
it wails as it wants to eat it;
seeing something nice,
it cries as it wants to play with it.
In maturity
one curbs the dispositions and pares down the desires,
making an effort to do the good.
Liú Xiang denies this, saying,
"If it were as Xunzi says,
then there would be no qi from Heaven.
If yin and yang, good and evil, do not exist, side-by-side, [in the nature],
then what is the cause of gooddeeds? [meaning, the human nature must have both good and bad in it, not just bad as Xunzi alleges].
Lù Jia says:
"When heaven-and-earth give birth to men,
they confer a nature of rites and duty.
Those who can discern the reason why they received the life-mandate, then they act in accordance [with heaven-and-earth's principles].
Such acts in accordance with them we (P.138)call Dao.
Lù Jia knew that with men, rites and
a sense of duty constitute the human nature.
However, those whose nature it is to do good
do good of their own before they discern [the right];
whereas those whose nature it is to do
evil, despite their ability to discern it,
still turn their backs on the rites and rebel against duty.
A sense of duty is derived from the good [aspects].
it cannot be constructed through artifice.
Thus greedy types can speak of honest men,
and those who engage in misrule can speak of good rule.
Robber Zhi condemned others' theft
and Zhuāng Qiāo rebuked others' excess.
They were discerning enough tounderstand themselves,
and they could mouth on about moral worth.
[But] their natures were bad, so they did not do [the good].
What possible benefit was [their level of discernment] with respect to doing good?
So Lù Jiǎ's theory
was not quite capable of getting at the [whole] truth.
When Dǒng Zhòngshū read the writings of Mencius and Xunzi,
he then devised his own theory of the dispositions and nature, which said,
"The great warp thread of Heaven
is now yin and now yang.
The great warp thread of human existence
is now the dispositions and now the nature.
The nature is born of yang,
The yin is coarse
and the yang [being more refined] [tends toward] the humane.
Those who insist that human nature is good are,
in fact, seeing its yang aspects.
Those who proclaim it to be evil are,
in fact, seeing the yin1." 92
By Dǒng Zhòngshu's theory,
Mencius saw its yang,
and Xunzi saw its yin.
It was permissible for Dong to base
himself in what the two experts each had seen;
but he fell short [of getting the whole [picture]
when he did not base his theory in the fact that human dispositions and natures 92 have some good parts
and some bad.
The human dispositions and the human nature are both born of yin and yang.
Being born of yin and yang,
they may be ample or thin.
Jade is born of stone,
so some is pure in color and some is mixed.
Since human dispositions and nature are born of yin and yang,
how could they be completely good?
Dǒng Zhòngshū's theory
has not quite gotten at the truth.
Liú Xiang said:
"Human nature refers to
what is so at birth.
it inheres in one's person and does not (P.140)reveal itself.
The human disposition [by contrast]
refers to what is so in response to things;
it assumes a form outside.
The external form we call yang.
And the as yet unexpressed we call yin.
Now, by Liu Xiang's theory
human nature refers to what is inside the person, as yet unexpressed.
When a natural disposition comes in contact with things, and
its form emerges on the outside; 93
hence the name yang [for it].
Human nature does not come out,
so it does not make contact with things;
hence its characterization as yin.
Now, if we follow Liu Xiang's theory,
we then are saying that the human dispositions are yang and the human nature is yin.
Liu did not base himself on what originally produced them.
He simply determined whether they were yin or yang [based on a single criterion]:
whether they were visible or not.
If one invariably whatever takes form as yang,
then the human nature, too, makes contact with things.
"In moments of haste, one cleaves to it;
and in more relaxed moments, one cleaves to it."93
"To act with compassion, not be able to endure cruelty"93 -- [that saying]
would identify "being unable to endure cruelty" as the qi corresponding to humankindness.93
Humility, modesty, declining and yielding -- they are
external expressions of the human nature.
[Because the human nature] makes some contact with [external things],
then compassion, humility, and modesty
assume form on the outside.
He says that the human nature, being inside, does not make contact
I fear his theory cannot be right.
Not to discuss the good and bad aspects of human nature,
only to talk about inside and outside, yin and yang --
it is hard to deduce much from such reasoning.
And besides, if we follow Liú Xiang's theory,
taking human nature as yin
and dispositions as yang,
then does the endowed human disposition93
in the end have good and bad in it, or not?
From Mencius on down to Liú Xiang,
the greatest classicists, the most widely-read scholars,
we have seen how numerous they are.
However, when it comes to analyzing human nature and human dispositions,
in the end not a one could ascertain the right.
Only men like Shì Shuo93
and Gōngsūn Nízǐ (P.141)
nearly got the right idea.
From this we may deduce,
it is easy to understand a phenomenon,
and still be difficult to put it into words.
Abundant writings and rich records
may be brilliant as flowers in bloom;
exaggerations and quick retorts
may be as sweet as sugar and honey.
But they do not necessarily get at the truth, for all that.
The truth is,
the human nature has good and bad in it;
just as person's talent may have high and low.
The high cannot go low.
Nor the low go high.
To say that human nature has no good or bad
is to say that human talents have no high or low.
The endowment of the human nature and the receipt of [Heaven's] predestined course,
are essentially alike.
Destinies have noble and low,
natures have good and bad.
To say that human nature has not good and bad
is to say that men's destinies have no noble and low.
The natures of the earth in the fields in the Nine Provinces95
are not the same in quality.
Hence the range from yellow to red to black
and the difference in yield between the best, average, and the worst.
The big rivers and small streams are not all alike, 95
Hence there are flows that are clear and muddy
and courses that run east, west, south and north.
Men are endowed with the nature of heaven-and-earth;
they hold within the qi of the Five Constants.
Some are humane and some dutiful,
due to the disjunction between human nature and artful cultivation.
In deeds, whether one walks or soars
is attributable to the gap between human nature and factual knowledge.
The color of one's face may be white or black;
one's bodily form may be long or short.
This, up to old age and death,
cannot be altered,
because Heaven's nature makes it so.
I have clearly demonstrated that Mencius' views on human nature
refers to those above the average;
that Xunzi's views on human nature
refer to those less than average; (P.142)
and what Yáng Xióng holds, that human nature is a mixture of good and bad,
refers to average people.
If it's just a question of returning the classics and being in accord with the moral way,
then all of these can be used to promote public morality,
but if we would thoroughly understand the underlying notion of human nature,
The classicists in their discussions say that
Heaven-and-earth intentionally gave birth to humans.
This assertion is preposterous.
Now, when heaven and earth combine their qi,
humans are born of their own accord, by coincidence.
It is just like the case of the husband and wife joining their qi,
then a child is born on its own.
Now when the husband and wife join their qi,
they did not [necessarily] at the time want to have a child.
The natural dispositions and desires, being aroused, they joined [their qi],
and the qi being joined gives birth to a child.
And from the fact that husband and wife do not intentionally beget a child,
one may infer that heaven-and-earth do not intentionally beget human beings.
That being the case, that human beings are born in heaven-and-earth
is just like the fish being in a pond,
or the nits and lice being on human beings.
On account of the qi they are born
and the various species reproduce themselves.
That the myriad things are born between heaven-and-earth --
in every case it is one and the same phenomenon.
Tradition says
"If heaven-and-earth do not produce man on purpose,
and man is born on his own, by coincidence,
then
why do the men who analyze the matter say that heaven-and-earth is the furnace,
the myriad things are the bronze,
the yin and yang is the fire
and the process of fashioning is the work done?
In my opinion, thepotter and caster use fire
to melt the bronze and bake the vessels.
And so they make them [the vessels] on purpose.
But if you say that heaven-and-earth do not intentionally give birth to humans, 101 and
man is only born of himself, by coincidence,
can we say that the potter and caster
do not intentionally make vessels
and rather the vessels, by coincidence, are completed on their own?
Now, if a metaphor does not fit the facts,
it would be wrong to call it an analogy;
and if the written account does not match the truth,
〞it cannot be called accurate."
They say:
This metaphor about men's endowment of qi
cannot be perfect in every respect.
The [only] comparison is to the smelted bronze being poured into a mould,
and the vessels being fired getting the kiln's fire.
It does not mean that heaven-and-earth in giving birth to man
is the same as potting and smelting. "
[I reply] In raising metaphors,
people always bring up human activities.
Human activities have their structure,
which cannot be separated into discrete parts.
Whenever one tries to have a look at the contours of one's own head,
the head cannot but turn;
and whenever one uses one's hands totry to feel the foot's contours,
the foot cannot but move. [That is because]
the eyes and head are part of the same body form;
hands and feet are part of the same body structure.
Now, the potters and metal workers
first moistened clay to make vessel, as
they must make a mould to make the shape.
Thus they do it with a purpose.
They burn coal to start a fire, and
they must regulate the kiln's heat.
Thus they act with a specific goal in mind.
But when it comes to the bronze casting, when not all the bronze is equally finished,
and not all the fired vessels are completely perfect --
that is because [that part of the (P.145)process] is not a matter of intentional production.
Now, if Heaven cannot produce humans intentionally,
then its giving birth to the myriad things
is not a matter of intentionality, either.
When heaven-and-earth combine their qi,
things grow on their own, by coincidence.
Now, tilling and weeding, sowing and planting,
are acts intentionally done of behalf of some end.
But when it comes to their completion or their failure to ripen --
that [the crops] do on their own, by coincidence.
What shall I use to prove this?
If Heaven produced all the myriad things intentionally,
then it ought to love one another like kin;
it ought not to let them harm one another like bandits.
Someone might say:
"The qi of the Five Phases [is]
Heaven giving birth to the myriad things.
Because all things hold within the qi of the Five Phases, it is
the qi in each of the Five Phases(P.146)which in succession destroys [the next phase in the cycle]."
I say:
Heaven, of its own accord, ought to use one phase of qi
in giving birth to the myriad things.
It ought to bid them love one another;
it should not allow five phases of qi
to, on the contrary, to destroy one another."
Someone may say:
"Heaven intended to make things for use,"
and so it lets them harm one another.
Things that destroy one another complete one another.
Therefore Heaven uses the qi of the Five Phases
in giving birth to the myriad things,
and people use the myriad things to perform the myriad tasks.
If they could not subdue one another,
they could not employ one another;
if they could not destroy one another,
they could not be made to be of use.
If Metal does not destroy Wood,
Wood cannot become a utensil.
And if Fire does not smelt Metal,
Metal cannot become a vessel.
Thus all things that destroy each other [also] benefit each other.
Now, whatever things that have blood
subdue and bite and devour
one another precisely because
each and every one of the Five Phases qi
makes them act them in this way."104
I say:
If Heaven in giving birth to the myriad things
had wanted to allow them to make use of one another, and this meant that
they could not harm one another,
then in giving birth to tigers, wolves, serpents, snakes, wasps, and scorpions,
all of which hurt men,
did Heaven also intend that men be made use of by them?
A further point is, the body of one person
holds within the Five Phases qi.
Therefore the acts of one person
has [within it] the behavioral modes associated with the Five Constants.
"Five Constants"
refers to the Five Constants [norms] (P.147)of action.104
The Five Organs are within
so all the qi of the Five Phases are present.
If we were to follow the opinions cited,
living things that contain blood,
as they contain within the Five Phases qi,
must always injure one another.
Then does the individual person
whose chest houses the Five Organs
find that they harm one another [within the body's system]?
And does one's person conduct
acting on the mind to be dutiful104
injure itself?
And besides, where is the proof that
each of the Five Phases qi harms another,
and that living things must conquer one another?104
[The hypothetical opponent] replies:
"The yin Branch corresponds to Wood,
its animal being the tiger;104
The shu Branch corresponds to Earth,
its animal being the dog;
The branches chou and wei also are Earth, with
chou's animal being the ox,
and wei's the sheep.
Wood conquers Earth,
and so the dog, ox, and sheep are conquered by the tiger.
The hai Branch is Water,
its animal being the pig;
Si is Fire,
its animal being the snake;
Zi is Water, too,
its animal being the rat;
Wu is Fire, also,
