Water conquers Fire,
and so the pig eats the snake.
Fire is hurt by Water,
and so when the horse eats rat (P.148)excrement then its belly swells."
To this I say:
"If it were truly as the discussant says,
there would also be signs that certain living things do not conquer one another.
The horse is the animal for wu.
and zi's is the rat.
You's is the chicken
and mao's the hare.
If Water conquers Fire,
why doesn't the rat pursue the horse [for food]?
If Metal conquers Wood,
why does the chicken not peck at the hare?
Hai is the pig,
and chou is the pig.
If Earth conquers Water,
why do the ox and sheep not slaughter the pig?
Si is the snake.
and shen is the monkey.
If Fire conquers Metal,
why does the snake not eat the macaque?
The macaque
is afraid of the rat.
The animal which sinks its teeth into the macaque
is the dog.
The rat is Water,
and the macaque is Metal.
Water does not conquer Metal, so
why does the macaque fear the rat?
The shu is Earth,
and shen is the monkey [that belongs to Metal].104
Earth does not conquer Metal, so
why does the monkey fear the dog?
The east is Wood,
its stars [taken together] constitute the Green Dragon.
The west is Metal,
its stars constitute the WhiteTiger.
The south is Fire,
The north is Water,
its stars constitute the Black Warrior.
The sky contains the refined and concentrated qi in the stars of the four directions,
which in coming down give birth to the bodies of these four animals.
All living things with blood
regard these four animals as the (P.151)leaders. {That's because it's]
most obvious in the case of these four animals that the Five Phases qi is
contained within.
In my judgment,
the dragon and tiger do not injure one another when they meet,
nor do bird and turtle harm one another.
If we use the four directional animals to prove a point,
or verify it by the twelve animals corresponding to the twelve two-hour periods,
then the Five Phases' creatures that use their qi natures to hurt one another
are not especially good cases of [the principle of] mutual response.
In general, the myriad things [all ] injure and destroy one another,
Living things with blood as a rule subdue one another, [so much so that]
they even bite or eat each other.
On their own, their teeth are blunt and sharp;
their muscle strength, superior and inferior.
[That fact makes] the movements [of some] agile,
their spirits courageous and their positions superior.
As men live in the phenomenal world,
their force is not equal to their opponents',
nor is their strength the same.
Naturally they come to conquer and subdue one another.
In using their strength to subdue one another,
as a rule they use blades to destroy one another.
Now, men destroying one another with blades is
just like animals using their teeth, horns, or claws
to butt or stab one another.
[The animal with] great strength, sharp horns,
with fiery spirit and long teeth,
will be able to win, as a rule.
And those with weak spirit, short claws,
a defeatist attitude, and blunt spurs
will, as a rule, be those which submit (P.152)due to their fears.
Men can be audacious or cowardly,
and this means in battle there will be victors and losers.
The victors have not necessarily received Metal qi;
the losers have not necessarily gotten the essential qi of Wood.
Confucius, being afraid of Yáng Hǔ,
stepped backwards, sweating.
Yáng Hǔ's skin color was not necessarily white,

In a single audience hall

Using one's tongue to debate or litigate

Now, when things conquer one another,
some use their spirit and position,
and some use their cleverness.
A small one, with spirit and an advantageous position,
whose mouth and feet are quick,
will as a rule with its small size overpower the big.
A big one without physical strength,
whose horns or wings are weak,
will as a rule with its big size submit to the small.
The magpie eats the hedgehog's skin;

It's because neither the hedgehog nor the snake is nimble.
The strength of a mosquito or a gadfly does not compare with that of the ox or horse.
The ox and the horse are tormented by the mosquito and the gadfly, [however]
for it is the insects that have the advantage in position.
The horns of the stag are adequate to butt the dog;
the hands of the monkey are enough to catch the rat;
Nonetheless, the stag is ruled by the dog

Thus the mature ox 113
is driven by the young herdboy

we do not take their point of origin, in the capital or the wilds, to be the single criterion for judging excellence.
During the Zhou period, the empire experienced the Great Peace.
The Yuechang offered a pheasant in tribute (P.219)to the Duke of Zhou.
When Gaozong got it [a pheasant], he would have considered it lucky..
The pheasant also is a creature of the wilds,
so why consider it lucky?
If it is because one part of the character for pheasant looks like that meaning a "well-born person,"
then the character for "a St. Peter's deer"154 also has a part that looks like the character for "noble man."
When Gongsun Shu got the white deer,
why did it predict something inauspicious?
That being the case, then the auspicious or inauspicious character of the pheasant
cannot be known [in advance],
nor can the good or evil character of the mulberry and gu
be proven.
The two trees perhaps are good things
signifying the well-born men from afar.
[Both] were on the verge of appearingin Gaozong's temple.
Therefore, Gaozong got the auspicious blessings
and he enjoyed a very long life.
Specialists in portent theory believe it
to be true that Heaven produces disasters
and portents in order to provide a warning for the king.
(P.220)[They believe that]
when a king commits an error,
a prodigy appears in the state.
And that if he does not change his ways,
the disasters are revealed in grasses and plants.
And if he does not change his ways,
the disasters are revealed in the Five Grains.
And if he does not change his ways,
the disaster will affect his person.
Mr. Zuo's traditions on the Spring and Autumn Annals say,
"Even when a state is on the verge of extinction,
it is seldom that the five grains do not ripen."
If disasters are revealed, [as they say,] in the Five Grains,
how can the Five Grains ripen?
That they do not ripen
is a sure sign that [the state] is on the verge of extinction.
Disasters likewise have their ominous responses, where the state being
on the verge of extinction causes the Five Grains not to ripen.
Heaven makes something not ripen.
Sometimes that is a disaster
and sometimes a blessing.
If the reality -- whether it is a calamity or a
blessing -- cannot be predicted,
then how could the talk of the two trees
be known for sure?
The experts in discourse who write in their books all say,
"For Heaven to rain down grain is inauspicious.
The written traditions say,
"When Cang Jie invented writing,
Heaven rained down grain, and
the ghosts wailed in the night."
As to this response perfectly in accord with an evil event --
why would Heaven employ a method with ripened grain?
If we concede 154that it comes down from
then we still should call it good.
How much better, then, is ripened grain that comes down with the rain!
If we follow the logic out to the end,
how could it possibly be considered inauspicious?
Now, as we all know, when the yin and yang are in harmony, then the grain ripens.
Otherwise, it suffers disaster.
Yin and yang in harmony
is the way proper to grain.
How could it possibly be said to be inauspicious?
Raw silk is made into pongee;
hemp is made into cloth.
To give a person silk and hemp thread
is still considered a valuable gift.
How much more valuable is it to confer upon a person woven silk and hemp!
Now, silk and hemp thread is like yin and yang,
and woven silk and hemp is like ripe grain.
If to gift a person with woven silk is not called "inauspicious," then
why call Heaven's conferral to them of grain "inauspicious"?
Now, if one cannot predict whether to rain down grain is lucky or not,
an explication of the mulberry and gu cannot be figured out in advance.
Let us take the case of fragrant grass growing during the Zhou period.
The entire empire experienced the Great Peace,
and people came to offer fragrant grass in tribute.
Fragrant grass is also a thing of the wilds,
so how does it differ from those two trees?
If we think that [only] so long as the Yi and Di offered it, then it was auspicious,
then if the fragrant grass grew in the Zhou royal domain,
would we be willing to call it good?
That its fragrance is so very penetrating
is why, as one begins the sacrifice, one pours the fragrant wine to bring down the gods.
Provided that it grew itself in the Zhou court,
it would have been no different in species from the felicitous grain, the vermilion
grass, and the "month plant."
That being the case, the mulberry likewise feeds the silkworm, and
and the silkworm makes the silk thread,
which is then made into woven silk cloth,
which is then made into clothes.
If those clothes then are taken into the ancestral temple as court robes,
the mulberry is precisely the same as thefragrant grass.
How can it possibly be called inauspicious?
When the heir to Duke Xian of Wei went to the Numinous Terrace,
a snake wrapped itself around the left wheel [of his chariot].
The driver said,
"Heir apparent, please get down and bow to it.
I have heard that when the son of our ruler
has a snake wind itself around the chariot wheel, he will quickly gain the state."
The heir apparent thereupon refused to descend from the chariot, and the heir
made him return to his residence.
When the driver [next?] saw the heir,
the heir said,
"I have heard that as a son
I should be completely in accord with my ruler.
I should in no way pursue my selfish desires
but instead in all reverence uphold his orders,
If I were now to obtain the state, that
would entail our ruler's loss of security.
To only regard the profit from [possession of ] the state
while ignoring our ruler's peace of mind --
that is absolutely not the way proper to a good son.
To bow so as to gain the state --
that would be to deny our ruler's desires.
To set aside the way proper to a son would be unfilial;
to contravene our ruler's wishes would be disloyalty.
And now you want me to do this --
well, that is tantamount to my wantingto endanger the state, clearly."
Then the heir threw himself from the audience hall, 156 in an attempted suicide.
His driver stopped him, but he could not prevent him [from making a second attempt],
whereupon [the heir] fell on his sword and died.
Now, if the snake curling around the left wheel
really meant the heir's speedy attainment of the state,
the heir apparent should not have died,
and Duke Xian ought to have died quickly.
In this our case, Duke Xian did not die
and the heir fell under his sword.
The driver's prediction
was a vulgar falsehood.
Perhaps in this case the snake was an evil omen that the heir was on the point of dying.
Since the driver believed the vulgar prediction, so he
misunderstood the reality of good luck and ill.
Now the growth of the mulberry and gu
is similar in categorical logic to the snake curling round the left wheel.
The snake's arrival really was unlucky, but
the driver thought it auspicious.
The mulberry and gu really were lucky, but
Zuyi thought them inauspicious.
When Yu on his journey south crossed the Yangzi,
there was a yellow dragon bearing up the boat.
The men in the boat
turned every sort of color, being at a loss, but
Yu [just] laughed delightedly, and said,
"I have received my destiny from Heaven,
and I am to exert every effort to show my concern for the masses.
Life is a journey;
death is a return.
Since death is going back,
why should [the prospect of] it be enough to upset my equanimity?
I look upon the dragon as if it is a lizard."
(P.224)The dragon then disappeared.
In my judgment,
the dragons of today and yesteryear, whenever they appeared, were always auspicious,
but the reason why Yu claimed that the yellow dragon, as an exception, was inauspicious was because the
people in the boat were afraid when they
saw it bearing the boat on its back.
Now, if we compare the two trees to the dragon,
it is roughly similar
even though the good luck and ill are reversed.
The wild grass growing in court
still can be considered unlucky,
in much the same way as the prodigy of the yellow dragon bearing up the boat.
Thus, it was taken as lucky and the Yin court did not perish.
When Duke Wen of Jin and King Cheng of Chu were about to
do battle at Chengpu,
a comet came out of the Chu lands.
Chu grasped the handle [of the broom]156
and [Duke Wen] asked Jiu Fan [about it].
Jiu Fan replied,
"When one uses a broom to fight,
the one who fends it off wins.
Duke Wen dreamt that he wrestled with King Cheng,
and King Cheng, who was on top,
sucked out his brains.
He asked Jiu Fan about it,
and Jiu Fan replied,
Your majesty was facing Heaven,
and King Cheng was facing down [for] his crimes.
The battle will most certainly be a great victory."
Duke Wen accepted his account, and
he greatly smashed the Chu troops.
Had Duke Wen asked an ordinary official,
he would certainly have said,
"we will not win."
Why is that?
A broomstar has no auspicious connotation,
and there is nothing particularly (P.225) inauspicious in having one position in wrestling.
Now, in the prediction about the mulberry and gu,
the prediction made it out to be inauspicious,
just as it was considered unlucky when Jin confronted the broomstar and losing the upper hand in wrestling.156
That being the case, what is auspicious
is tantamount to the bizarre explanations about confronting comets and facing up toward the sky.
Thus, Gaozong lived a very long time
and the Yin reign did not perish.
If Duke Wen had not asked Jiu Fan, and
Jiu Fan had not clearly stated the auspicious character [of the prodigy] ,
then when the battle was a great victory,
the men of the age would have said,
"Duke Wen used his most worthy virtue to
defeat Chu's immorality.
Even though Heaven made the evil prodigy appear,
and even though [Duke Wen] in bed had a bad dream,
he still can destroy an evil portent and excise the inauspicious in order to gain good fortune."
And since Yin did not have Jiu Fan's extraordinary knowledge,
but instead it had Zuyi's gullible prediction,
so the text about the mulberry and gu
has come down through the ages, undisturbed. And
the talk that turned calamity into blessing
has not been shown up for what it is even up (P.226)to today.
The classicists' transmitted texts say,
At the time of Yao,
ten suns came out at the same time.
The myriad things were burnt to a crisp.
Yao shot an arrow up at the ten suns,
and he got rid of nine of them, so
one sun always [now] comes out.
This saying is a falsehood.
Now, in archery, the force of an
arrow is spent at less than a hundred
paces, certainly.
The sun's course
makes its way through the sky, along the ecliptic.
The distance between Heaven and
man is measured in the tens of (P.227)thousands of miles.
When Yao shot up at them,
how could he possibly have hit the sun?
If we suppose that at the time of Yao
the distance between Heaven and Earth
was less than one hundred paces,
then when Yao shot at the suns,
the arrow would have been able to reach them.
But if the distance surpassed one hundred paces,
it would not have been able to hit it.
If we suppose that at the time of Yao
the distance between Heaven and Earth was such that
Yao's shot hit them,
the shot would still not have been able to damage the suns.
And had it damaged the suns, why would they have been willing to go away?156
Why is that?
The sun is made of fire.
If a fire on earth
was put near a torch, and
men were to shoot at it from the side,
how could it extinguish the fire, even if the arrow hit the mark?
And if a fire on earth would not be extinguished by being hit,
then why would a fire in the sky be expelled by being hit?
These writings want to say that
Yao used his superior 156integrity to shoot at it, and that when
such superior integrity was applied,
[even] metal and stone would beweakened.
It is evident that integrity, having no hardness,
so it has no distance either.156
Now water and fire
each have a single basic nature.
If one were able to shoot at a fire and extinguish it,
then one ought to be able to shoot at water and get rid of it.
At the time of the great flood [under Yu],
the flood waters inundated the Central States,
doing great harm to the common people.
So how is it that Yao did not extend his superior integrity [to this flood],shoot at it and get rid of it?
[That would mean that] Yao could shoot at the suns,
disarming their fire, but
he could not shoot at the Yellow River in such a way that he
caused it to do no harm.
Now, if one cannot cause the waters to withdraw by shooting at them,
then we know that the tale of shooting at the suns
is a falsehood, not the truth.
Someone might say that
the suns were qi.
So while an arrow shot might not have reached them,
superior integrity would have destroyed them.
Now the heavens are also faraway.
If we suppose them to be composed of qi,
then they are made of the same material as the sun and moon.
And if we suppose them to be a physical body,
then they are comparable with metal and stone.
To assume that Yao's superior integrity
could destroy suns and weaken metal and stone, then
when he shot at the sun was he able to penetrate the heavens?
The world claims that Jie and Zhou's evils [included]
shooting at the heavens and beating the earth.
And when the world praises Gaozong's virtue, [it says that]
his rule made the mulberry and gu tree [omens] disappear.
If Yao could not use his virtue to extinguish the ten suns,
but instead he had to shoot at them with an arrow,
that would mean that his virtue did not measure up to that of Gaozong,
and his evil was the same as that of (P.228)Jie and Zhou.
How is it that he could use his superior integrity
to wrest a response from Heaven?
The transmitted texts say:
When King Wu launched a punitive campaign against Zhou,
he crossed Meng Ford.
The waves of Yanghoū60 crashed against [the boat] against the current;
There was violent winds and utter darkness, such that
neither men nor horses could be seen.
At that point, King Wu grasped in his left hand a yellow halberd,
and in his right a white standard.
With eyes bulging, he brandishedit, saying,
"So long as I am alive,
who in the empire dares to thwart my plan!"
At that, the winds abated and the waves subsided.
Such talk is a falsehood.
When King Wu crossed Meng Ford,
the hosts of knights were in high spirits, with those in
front singing songs and those in back dancing.
Heaven and man experience the same sort of responses.
That men would be delighted andHeaven angry
is not really appropriate.
That those in front sang while those in back danced
is not necessarily the truth.
That one [could] brandish [his standard] in the winds and thereby stop them --
the reports verge on falsehood.
Now wind is qi.
The theorists consider it to be
the commanding voice of Heaven-(P.229)and-Earth.
If King Wu's punishment of Zhou was proper,
Heaven ought to have calmed [the wind and waves] so as to help him.
And if his punishment of Zhou was wrong,
then heaven's storm represented its anger.
If King Wu was not upholding Heaven's command,
and seeking to discover his own errors,
for him to say with bulging eyes,
"So long as I am alive,
who in the empire would dare to thwart my plans?"
would [only] increase Heaven's anger
and add to his own evil deeds.
Why would the winds have been willing to stop?
When parents get angry
at the child who does not mend its ways, and
the child yells back, with bulging eyes,
are the parents willing to pardon him?
If the winds are caused by Heaven
it is the calamitous qi which is self-so (causing itself to be so??);
it, too, lacks a consciousness.
It is not possible that bulging eyes and a brandished flag would cause them to stop.
Now the winds are like the rains.
Do you suppose that King Wu could stop the rains with bulging eyes and a
brandished standard?
If King Wu could not thereby stop the rains,
then he could not by this means stop the winds, either.
Perhaps just at this time King Wu did brandish his standard, and
the wind by chance stopped of its own accord.
The world in praising King Wu's virtue
then claims that King Wu could stop the wind.
The transmitted texts say that
when Duke Xiang of Lufought with Han,
in the thick of battle, the sun went down.
The duke grasped his lance and brandished it, causing
the sun to retreat the space of three(P.230)lunar mansions.
Such a saying is a falsehood.
In general, men who can use their superior integrity to move Heaven
must concentrate their minds and have a single focus [they say].
Delegating [other] duties and gathering their forces,
the concentrated will gets through to Heaven, and
Heaven is moved by it.
Still, [such an account] cannot be said to be true.
Duke Xiang's aspirations were focused on the battle;
if he brandished once [his lance] on account of the sun's going down,
how was he able to order the sun to retreat?
Even if we suppose that a sage could make such a gesture at the sun,
the sun in the end would not retreat.
What sort of man was Duke Xiang
that he could cause the sun to retreat?
The "Great Plan" says:
Some stars have a propensity for wind,
and some for rain.
"Due to the course of the sun and moon
winter alternates with summer.(P.231)
The moon's following the stars
causes there to be wind and rain."
Now, as we all know, the stars are made of the same concentrated essence as the sun and moon.
If the sun and moon did not follow the stars,
the stars suddenly would revert.
That makes it clear that the course of the sun and moon has its constant degrees. [Sun and moon]
cannot follow the stars' likes and dislikes, so
how could one of them follow Duke Xiang's wishes?
The stars' locations in the heavens
constitute the mansions for the sun and moon.
This is like earth having post stations [on it], which
serve as temporary residences for senior officials.
The twenty-eight lunar mansions have their divisions,
with one mansion equal to ten degrees,
more or less.(P.232)
That means that if the sun retreated three mansions,
it was some 30 degrees.
The sun every day traverses one degree. {The tale says that]
within the instant of one gesture
it went back thirty days' worth of degrees.
That would be like saying that a mansion was equal to a degree, and
that three degrees would also be three day's travel, and that
within the instant of one gesture
the sun was caused to retreat three days' worth. [They also say that]
Duke Jing of Song, expressing his integrity,
uttered three good sayings,
and the Glittering Deluder moved three mansions.
Those who speak the truth still call it a falsehood.
Duke Xiang in the heat of battle
was upset at the sun's going down,
and so, on account of this, he brandished his lance.
He was entirely lacking in integrity and he had uttered no good words;
that the sun, on account of his gesture, would retreat
is hardly credible!161
An another point: The sun is fire.
The sage who brandishes something at a fire
in the end would not be able to make it retreat.
Duke Xiang brandished something at the sun, so
how could he possibly have made it retreat?
Perhaps, in this one instance, during the battle, the sun was directly at mao[= due east].
In the confusion of battle,
he thought the sun was going down,
so he brandished his lance and turned to the left;
having reversed his own course, the sun appeared to him to have retreated.
The world loves a divine prodigy
and so it followed him in saying thatthe sun had retreated; and
they did not say what I am saying.162
The transmitted texts say that Jing
Ke, acting on behalf of Yan's heir
apparent, planned to assassinate the King of Qin.
A white ring of clouds pierced the sun.
A gentleman from Wei on behalf of Qin
devised the plan [of battle] for Changping,
but the Great White [Venus] eclipsed 163the Pleiades.
This says that its [or their, meaning the heroes'?] concentrated essence moved the heavens,
and that the heavens on its [or their] account was influenced to change.
Now, it is true to say that a white ring
of clouds pierced through the sun, and
the Great White eclipsed the Pleiades.
But it is a lie to say that Jing Ke's plot
made August Heaven move in
response, and
that is why the white clouds pierced
the sun and the Great White eclipsed the Pleiades.
Now, using chopsticks to strum the bell
or divination sticks to beat the drum
one cannot make them sound.
That's because what one uses to strum and beat
is small.
Now human forms do not exceed seven Han feet.
To use a form that size to strike a pure spirit,
hoping to have an effect --
even if one gathers and sharpens one's ideas,
how could they move Heaven,
as they are like the sticks hitting the bell or beating the drum?
[It won't work] because even if one'sspirit has perfect integrity,
what is used to move it is small.
Besides, it was people that they wanted to hurt.
If the people were not moved, then
how is it that Heaven, by contrast, was moved?
An interlocutor says,
"Can men's hurtful qi move the
the others?"
I say that it cannot.
When Yurang wanted to harm Viscount Xiang of Zhao,
Xiangzi's heart was moved.
When Guan Gao wanted to rebel against the High Ancestor Gaozu,
Gaozu was similarly moved.
The two heroes nurtured in their breasts this concentrated vitality,
and so the two rulers were palpably shaken.
I reply:
"When a calamitous change is at hand,
one's own person exhibits strange signs;
it is not that a person right then is able to make them be moved.
What shall I use to prove it?
Sometimes we meet madmen on the road
who use a knife to hurt themselves.
It is not necessarily the case that the madmen intend to injure their own persons,
but that, prior to this, their persons already have [within] baleful omens.
From this I conclude
that the arrival of baleful omens
is the outward visible sign of calamitous changes that are inauspicious on their own,
and not the result of the desire to hurt oneself.
And another thing: men with inauspicious destinies get evil signs when they divine.
When it's milfoil divination, they get inauspicious hexagrams.
When they go out the door, they see what is unlucky,
and the danger predicted looks to calamitious qi,
which then appears on the countenance,
in precisely the same way that the (P.234)white clouds and the Great White appeared in the sky.
A change appears in the sky;
a baleful omen appears in the person.
Above and below fit perfectly,
as they are naturally reponding to one another, without any prompting.
The transmitted texts say,
When Dan, the Yan heir apparent, came [as hostage] to the Qin court,
he could not get permission to leave,
[though] he sought permission to go home from the Qin king.
The Qin king in detaining him
swore to him the following oath:
"If the sun rises twice to the noonday point,
and if the heavens rain down grain,
and if a crow grows a white head,
and the horse horns,
and the wooden images at the door of the kitchen grow feet of flesh --
then and only then may you have return."
Right at that time,
Heaven and Earth came to his aid,
so the sun appeared twice at the midday point,
the heavens rained down grain,
the crows grew heads of white
and horses grew horns,
and the wooden images by the kitchen door grew feet of flesh.
As the King of Qin took him for a sage wonder-worker,
he then let him go back home.
Such a tale is a falsehood.
What sort of man was the Yan heir
that he could move Heaven?
[True] sages imprisoned
were not able to move Heaven, so
how could the Yan heir, who was
[merely] a worthy man, bring this about?
Now, if Heaven was able to help the heir,
and so it produced all these auspicious signs in order to gain the release of his person,
then it ought to have been able to make the Qin king more balanced in his thoughts, and in this way secure [the heir's] release from his troubles.
To release someone from captivity -- that's a single deed and an easy one, too.
To produce these auspicious omens, [by contrast, takes five deeds and hard ones, too.
To forego doing one easy deed
to do five difficult deeds -- well,
why doesn't Heaven fear taking so much trouble?
Tang was confined at Xiatai;
King Wen was imprisoned at Youli;
Confucius was in straits between Chen and Cai.
The afflictions of these three sages
Heaven could not relieve.
If those who imprisoned them had seen any sign of Heaven's favor and considered them to be sages,
they would have let them go and heaped honors upon them.
Someone might object:
"But those who imprisoned the three (P.235)sages did not swear with each an oath.
And the three sages in their hearts did not desire [above all things their release].
And that is why the auspicious omens in aid of the sages had nothing prompting them to appear.
Heaven in aiding men
seems like lending people objects.
If people don't seek [to borrow anything],
they will not be given anything."
I say:
When the Yan heir wanted Heaven to send down auspicious omens,
he hardly said it in words.
He merely wished for it in his heart.
That being the case, when Tang was shut up at Xiatai,
and King Wen at Youli,
their hearts, too, would have wanted to get out.
And when Confucius was in straits between Chen and Cai,
his heart would have wanted food.
How is it that Heaven cause the locks at Xiatai and Youli to break, so that
Tang and Wu could walk out.
And how is it that Heaven did not rain down grain in Chen and Cai
so that Confucius could eat his fill?
The Senior Archivist said,
"The world claims that it was the Yan heir that caused Heaven to rain down
grain and horses to grow horns.
Probably this is all empty talk."
The Senior Archivist is a person who writes about true events in Han times
and for him to say that this is empty talk
is tantamount to saying it's a lie.
The transmitted texts say that when
Ji Liang's wife faced the city wall and
wailed, the city wall on account of it (P.236)collapsed.
This would mean that when Ji Liang
joined the army and did not return,
his wife was so distressed over it
that she faced the city wall and sobbed aloud,
she was so unalloyed in her distress
that the concentrated qi affected the city wall, which
in consequence collapsed on her account.
Now it is true to say that she faced
the city wall and wailed.
But it is lie that this was the reason for
the city wall's collapse.
Now there has never been a person who surpassed Yong Menzi in wailing.
When Yong Menzi wailed in front of Lord Mengchang,
the lord himself felt great grief on account of it.
Apparently, the concentrated integrity [behind] his wailing was such that it
affected those who faced him to feel utterly in despair.
Now Yong Menzi may have been capable of moving Lord Mengchang's heart.
The reason why he couldn't cause any response in Mengchang's robes
was that robes feel no pity;
they do not, therefore, make any meaningful contact with the human heart.
Now city walls are made of earth.
And earth is like the robes, in that
it lacks the organs of heart and belly.
So how could it be so moved by cries of distress that it collapsed?
If a sound that is pure could move the earth of the city wall,
then would wailing163 performed by a grove of trees
be able to snap the plants and break the trees?
And would sobbing by water or fire
be able to boil water or extinguish fire?
Now, there really is no [major] difference between plants and trees, water and fire, and earth.
That being the case, it's absolutely clear that Ji Liang's wife would not be 明矣。 capable to causing the wall to collapse.
Perhaps, in this single instance, the city wall happened to collapse on its own, and perhaps
Ji Liang's wife right then wailed.
Later ages really like the lie,
and they never sought the origin behind the true circumstances.
Hence, the phrase about the wall's collapse
has continued unabated down to modern times.
The transmitted texts say that
Zou Yan was innocent of all crime,
but he was imprisoned in Yan.
Right at that time, it was summer, the fifth month,
and he looked up to Heaven and sighed loudly, [with the result that]
Heaven sent down frost on his behalf.
This is no different from the story
about the effect of wailing by Ji Liang's wife's .
I.e., it's true, his innocence and
imprisonment, and his loud sighs
as he looked up to Heaven in summer.
But it's a lie to say that Heaven let
frost fall on his behalf.
Now, were ten thousand people to let out audible sighs together,
they still would not be able to move Heaven.
How could Zou Yan, a single
person, let out a single sigh of resentment that caused the frost to fall?
Zou Yan's feelings of resentment
did not surpass those of Zengzi and Boqi.
Zengzi let out a murmur, when he was under suspicion.
Amd Boqi sang a song when he was exiled.
To be under suspicion is much the same thing as being imprisoned.
And murmurs and songs are comparable with sighs.
If Zengzi and Boqi could not bring on the cold,
then what sort of man was Zou Yan
that he alone could make the frost fall?
The resentment engendered by being exiled
need hardly be mentioned.
Shensheng fell under his sword,
and Wu Zixu cut his throad.
The former was truly filial, but he was given death;
the latter was absolutely loyal but he suffered execution.
And one more point: Each of them, on the point of death, uttered ringing phrases, which,

"It is a lucky omen,
you can use it to sacrifice the spirits."

n rewarding people.

When the minister of Chǔ, Sūn Shūáo, was a boy,(P.266)
he beheld a two-headed snake,
then he killed and buried it.
After going home, he cried before his mother.
His mother asked what was the matter,
he replied:
"I have heared that one who sees a two-headed snake must die,
just now I come out
and see a two-headed snake.
I am afraid that I will leave you and die,
hence I weep."
His mother said:
"Where is the snake now?"
He answered:
"I fear that others will see it later,
so I have killed and buried it."
His mother said:
"I have heard that if one has a hidden virtue,
Heaven will recompense him.
You are certainly not going to die,
Heaven will reward you."
Shūáo did not die really,
and at last became the minister of Chǔ.
For burying one snake,
he received two favours.

I say that
it is idle talk.
That one who sees two-headed snake, always die,
is a common saying;
and that Heaven rewards one who has hidden virtue
is a common opinion.
Shūáo believed the common saying, then buried the snake;
and his mother convinced of the common opinion, then belived a reward.
Thus it means that life and death do not depend on one's fate,
just on the death of a snake.

then the dragon

strike and split trees,
demolish houses,

and that, when the thunder and the lightning kill a man,

The deep rolling sound
is the sound of Heaven's angry,

Now, when the thunder breaks out,
one fluid is set in motion, and one sound produced.

and that when they kill a man,

which is not corrsepondent with the principle.
Those who talk about this matter regard that the deep rolling sound
is the roaring of Heaven's angry.
That would be appropriate to punish the guilty,
but would not be suitable to fetch a dragon.
It is possible that when punishing the guilty,
Heaven may be angry. (P.294)
But when it fetches a dragon,
what faults has it, that Heaven sould be angry with it?

ought not to be angry.

Heaven does not fetch it;
but having killed a dragon,
Heaven fetches it.
What different is there between human guilt and that of dragons[there is no different between human guilt and that of dragons],
and why does Heaven use a different methods to kill them?

The deep rolling sound falls upon one's head,
hence it can kill him.

kill a man?
When a man has been killed by a thunderbolt,
by examing his body,
one would discover traces of burning.
If Heaven used the angry breath of its mouth,
then could the angry breath of its mouth become fire?
Moreover, the mouth adheres to the body,
and the mouth moves with the body.

its sound is close to the earth;
and when the thunder falls into a decline,
its sound is near to the sky.
Now, according to this,
when the sound is close to the earth,
the mouth must approach the earth,
and the body also should be so.
But when the thunder rolls swiftly and violently,

we do not see it coming down.
Since we do not see it descending,
then we know that the deep rolling sound
is not Heaven's anger.
Heaven's anger is not different from that of human.
When a man is angry,
his voice sounds loud, if he comes near others;
and if he is far away from others, his voice becomes low.

but its body far away,
which is out of the fact that Heaven is in anger.

its mouth being in the East, the West, the South, or the North,

"Heaven has really moved towards the East, the West, the South, or the North,

people could not behold it."

" A hundred Li 3 are frightened by the thunder."

Whenever the mouth moves, the entire Heaven must move its place,

that Heaven follows the movements of its mouth.

The Spirit of Heaven,
or the dark blue sky?

If it means the dark blue sky,
but the sky is a substance, it cannot become angry,
for angry requires a mouth.
Heaven and Earth
are like a husband and a wife,
who are the father and mother of mankind.

his father got angry,
and beat him to death,
would his mother not weep for him?
Now, if Heaven in its wrath kills a man,

and never hears of Earth's crying.
If Earth cannot cry,
then Heaven also cannot gets angry.

Heaven becomes angry and kills him;
if one has secret virtues,

the knowledge of Heaven arises fome that of human.

killing men ocasionally,

should not be a same noise.

The Confucian scholars of our time
tend to believe their teachers and approve of antiquity.
They imagine that anything the worthies and sages proposed is never wrong (morally or factually),
they focus all their energies expounding and reciting their texts,
and they have no idea how to raise objections or pose problems.
In fact, when worthies and sages used their brushes to create texts
their purpose was to be correct in details and meticulous,
but still they cannot be considered to have got to the facts in all cases.
How much less, when they speak out in haste,
can they in all cases be right?
They cannot be right in all cases,
but the men of our (or: their) times had no idea of how to raise objections,
In some cases they were right,
but their underlying idea was submerged and hard to see,
and the men of our (or: those?) times had no idea of how to raise problems.
NB:
in the pronouncements of the worthies and sages
there are often mutual contradictions between what comes first and last;
in their written compositions
what has been written earlier is often in logical conflict with what comes afterwards.
The men of learning of our times
were unable to understand this properly.
Their proponents all say as follows:
"The followers of Confucian school,
with the talents of the seventy men,
are superior to the Confucians of the present age."
This statement is misguided.
Those people take the view that Confucius was a teacher.
and that when a sage transmits the Way
he will invariably pass it on to men of remarkable talent,
and therefore they imagine these disciples are extraordinary.
But the talents of the men of antiquity
were the talents of the men of the present age.
But what we call heroes today
the ancients imagined to have been sages and men of supernatural talents.
Consequently they imagine that through the ages there have been few of the kind of these seventy men.
Supposing that in this age there were a teacher like Confucius
then the learned men of this age
would all be men of the kind of Yán and Mǐn;
and supposing there had been no Confucius [Vossian proper name]
men like the seventy men
would have been [like] today's Confucians.
How does one prove this?
It is because those who studied with Confucius
could not ask the ultimately decisive questions.
The statements of the Sage
one cannot understand completely,
in explaining the Way and laying out the principles or rectitude
he was unable always to bring out things into the open.
When someone is unable always to bring things out into the open
one should bring up problems in order to get them out.
and if someone is unable to expain things completely
one should make objections in order to get the ultimate points.
When Gāo Yáo laid out the Way for Emperor Shùn
he was being shallow, sketchy, and did not get to the ultimate point.
But Yǔ raised problems and objections against him
so his shallow statements became more profound,
and his sketchy points became more articulated.
It would appear that because he raised problems and objections 279
Gāo Yáo's explanations became focussed, and they became more profound and incisive.
Because he met resistance he made himself abundantly clear.
When Confucius laughed at Zǐyóu's singing with zither accomaniment, 279
Zǐyóu quoted previous statements by Confucius to fend him off/keep him at bay like an enemy.
From the present perspective and judging by the text of the Analects
Confucius' statements often were like those formulations he used when he was ridiculing the zither-accompanied singing.
Rarely did disciples raise objections like Zǐyóu.
As a result, Confucius' statements
ended up in a tangle und unresolved.
Because the seventy men were unable to raise objections
the Confucians of our age
cannot base themselves on the realities and speak of right and wrong.
In general, the method of learning how to raise objections
is not a matter of a lack of talent.
The hard part lies in keeping one's master at bay (and not allowing oneself to be intellectually subjugated),
in regarding the Way(truth of a matter) as essential, and rectitude as the substantial issue,
and to establish through evidence what is right and wrong.
And the Way of raising problems and objections
is by no means necessarily face-to-face with the sages, and while these are still alive.
As for those who unravel explanations and persuade others in our times
do not necessarily have to wait for a sage to instruct and inform them
before they presume to speak up.
If something is really a problem raised from ignorance of a neat explanation,
then when it comes to raising objections against Confucius
how can this be harmful to the right course/rectitude?
If one really has the understanding necessary for the transmission of the ultimate purpose of the sage,
then to launch a formal attack against Confucius' explanations
how could that go against proper principle?
I consider that when it comes to raising problems with Confucius' statements
and to raising objections against texts that have not been unravelled,
then the men of vast talent and great erudition in our world,
those men who are able to give immediate responses to problems posed, and who unravel objections,
should definitely appreciate that those in our world who raise difficulties and problems speak up on the issues of right and wrong.
Mèng Yìzǐ asked about filial piety.
The Master said:

The following problem arises:
When Confucius says "One should not be disobedient"
what one should not be disobedient towards is the rites.

and he ought not to contravene his parents' wishes.
But when Confucius said 'never disobey,'
he did not raise the issue of 'disobeying the rites.'
When Mèng Yǐzǐ heard Confucius' prounouncements,

"What did you mean?"

"While they are alive, serve them in accordance to ritual propriety,
and after they have died, bury them in accordance with ritual propriety
and sacrifice to them in accordance with ritual propriety."
Surposing that Fán Chǐ had not raised this problem,
the explanation of "one should not disobey" would have been impossibly to ascertain.
And Mèng Yìzǐ's talents
did not surpass those of Fán Chǐ.
Thus in the chapters of the Analects it does not spell out clearly the statements made and the actions involved.
Since Fán Chǐ did not understand,
will Mèng Yìzǐ have necessarily understood?? (In other words: he was left in the dark.)

Those who believe that the sun is near when it rises and sets,

When a fire comes near to us, then we feel warm,
when it is far away from us, then we feel cold.
Therefore, the sun is near while it is in the zenith,
and far away at its rising and setting.
Both views have their well-grounds,
hence it has not yet been ascertained, which is right, and which is wrong.
If we base our judgement on facts,
we think that the sun is near in the zenith, and at sunrise and sunset far off.
How to prove this?
We take this as an instance: Place a pole upright under a house.
In general, a house is thirty feet high.
Under the roof of a house,
a pole is established vertically,
its top touches the ridgepole,
and its bottom reaches the earth.
Thus it is thirty feet high from the ground to the ridgepole.
If the pole is put inclined,
then its top will diverge sidewards,
and cannot touch the ridgepole,
thus the distance from the ground (to the ridgepole) is more than thirty feet .
At noon,
the sun just reaches the highest point on heaven,
just as the pole is established upright,
that the distance from the ground (to the ridgepole) measures thirty feet .
At sunrise or sunset,
the sun deflects to men's right or left,
just like the pole diverges sidewards,
that the distance from the ground (to the ridgepole) measures more than thirty feet .
According to this,
it can be known clearly that
the sun in the zenith is near,
and far at its rising or setting.
Let's take another example: a man is seated in the certral hall of a house,
and another walk on its roof.
When he walks on the centre of the house,
he is just above the seating man,
thus the distance from the man on the roof
to the man seated in the house,
is thirty feet.
If the man on the roof were at the eastern or the western corner of the roof,
his distance from the man seating in the house
would be more than thirty feet.
The sun in the zinith is like the man in the middle of the roof,
and its rising and setting
is like the man being at the eastern or the western corner of the roof.
In the zenith the sun is near, therefore warm,
and at the time of its rising and setting, the sun is far, therefore cold.

By inspecting, we do not see that there are the "Six Institutions" in the present Lǐ,
there are no three hundred and sixty officers,
and also do not see (the rites about) the son of Heaven.
When were the rites of the son of Heaven abolished?
Were they oblished by the Qín?
In the time of Emperor Xuān, a woman in Hé Nèi demolishing an old house,
got a chapter of the lost Lǐ.
Which chapter was it
among the sixty chapters?
Gāo Zǔ order Shūsūn Tōng to formulate the Yípǐn,
(at that time, )the Yílǐ had to be formulated again,
where then were the sixteen chapters?
The present sixteen chapters Were
the remnans of those being burned by the fire of Qín?
How many chapters were there
during the Qín period?
I would ask those who study the Shījing1:

They would reply:
"At the decline of the Zhōu dynasty the Shījing was composed,
it maybe at the time of King Kāng.
The virtue of king Kōng had defect in his house[was fond of women],
and the great officers criticized his getting up late,
therefore the Shījing was produced."
In fact the prosperity of King Wén and King Wǔ lasted to the time of King Chéng and King Kōng,
since the time of King Kōng was not degenerate,
why was the Shījing written?
And there was not only one king in the Zhōu dynasty,
how do we know that it was written in the time of King Kōng?
In the late period of the two dynasty[Shāng and Xià], both have degenerated,
why was the Shījing not written
at the time of the decline of the Xià and the Shāng?
The Shàng Shū says:
"The Shījīng is the expression of earnest thought,
and the songs are the chanting of these expressions.
Consequently, at that time there must already have been the Shījing,
however, they cut off a section of those caming down from the Zhōu, and that it appeared in the Zhōu dynasty.
In ancient time the Odes were collected,
and every ode had its explanatory words.
But now the Shījing has no explanatory words,
how do we know it is because that when the Five Canons were burned by Qín,
the Shījing had not any remnants of its words????
I would also ask those who study the Chūnqīu:
"Under which king of the Zhōu dynasty was it
when Confucius wrote the Chūnqīu?
After he returned from Wèi to Lǔ,
then the music was edited,
and the Chūnqīu was wrotten.
His return from Wèi to Lǔ
falls in the time of Duke Āi.
But when he left from Wèi,
who is its ruler?
And in what manner did he treat Confucius,
that he composed the Chūnqīu after his return to Lǔ?
Confucius copied the chronicle to write Chūnqīu,
was the chronicle named Chūnqīu originally?
or was it called Chūnqīu after having been made into a Classic?
Those who study the law
are likewise scholars.

" Gāoyáo."
I refute:
"Gāoyáo
lived under the time of Yáo and Shùn.

Someone may say:
"Xiāo Hé."
I refute:
"Xiāo Hé
was a contemporary of Gāo Zǔ.
During the time of Emperor Xiào Wén,
a superintendent of the public granary in Qí, Chúnyú Yì commited an offence,56
and was summoned to Cháng-ān.
His daughter, Tíyíng sent a petition to the emperor for her father,
saying that once the corporal punishment was carried out,
there was no repantance.
Emperor Wén was touched by her words,
then changed[abolished] the corporal punishments.
By inspecting we know that the present Nine Statutes is symbolic punishements,
not corporal punishments.
Emperor Wén lived later than Xiāo Hé,
and we know that it was corporal punishment at that time.
Was what Xiāo Hé made
symbolic punishments, ???
hence they say that Nine Statutes were mady by Xiāo Hé?
In ancient time, there were three hundred rules of ceremony,
and there were three thousand rules of demeanour.
Of penalties there likewise were three hundred major punishments,
and three thousand minor items.
To violate ceremonies,
means being punished by punishments;
and what the ceremony rejected
was what the punishment accepted, ???
therefore both were of equal number.
Now, the present Lǐjīng are sixteen,
but the laws of Xiāo Hé merely have nine sections,
why are they not corresponding?
When the Five Classics were titled to their every chapter,
they all were distinguished according to their subjects.
As for the Lǐ and the L, they also are classics,57
when they were titled,
a chapter of the Lǐ was called Hūn Lǐ,
and a chapter of the L was called Dào L.
Why?
Now, we inquire generally the scholars with the meaning of old and modern institutions,
the scholars are unable to know;
and question differently them with the things concering their Classics,
they also cannot understand.
This is due to their fault that they only belive and stick to the knowledge of their teachers58
without reading a bit widely.???
The civil officials assum that they know official business,
and are proficient in official documents.
I would ask them:
"Since you are proficient in these matters,
should you be able to comprehend thoughly their theories,
and know completely their meaning?"
The civil officials will certainly be utterly ignorant.
I would ask them again, saying:
"In olden days, marquis were confered, every one control his territory;
now prefects and magistrates are appointed,
what does this means?
The ancient men had the joined field system,
people cultivated for their state;
now land taxs are levied in grain and grass,
what does this means?
People are sent to serve in army in their local area for one month every year,59
what does it base on?
At the age of twenty-three years, one has to be registered to serve in army,
from the fifteenth year, one has to pay the land tax,
and from the seventh year, one has to hand in poll-tax twenty-three,
what is it due to?
Under which ruler
was introduced the sacrifice which is held in the last month of a year?
Why the Spirits of the gate, the door, the well and the hearth
are set up?
Why should the God of the Land and the Grain, the Holy Farmer, and the Spirit of Star
be offered sacrifices?
At the end of a year, people expel sickness,
what do they expel?
People are bade to set up a human figure of peach wood at the door,
what is their purpose?
People suspend cords of reeds over the entrance,
and paint tigers on the door-screens,
what do they expel?
The wall are painted a man who is to quell fire,
what is the idea?
To what do the six feet of a pace,
and the six inches of a cap
correspond?
There is a commanding officer and a chancellor,
but no assisting under-secretary of State,
what rule is it?
Two prefects exchanging their documents use the phrase:

but two district magistrates do not say so,
how to explain this?
When a prefect report matters to the two Fǔ, he says

what style is that?
The eight degress of noblity are conferred upon the people,
what example does it follow?
and the titles are called Zān niǎo and Shàngzào,
what is the meaning?
Recording the merits of officials is termed Fāyuè,
what does it refer to?
At the age of seventy, one is presented with a imperial staff,
how did this custom arise?
The top of a stick is carved with a pigeon,
but not with a sparrow,
what sort of stick is it?
If the pigeon is considered auspicious,
why do they not confer a pigeon, but a pigeon staff,
and not a staff with a sparrow,
how to explain this?
A daytime is divided into sixty degrees,
the water in the clepsydra will drip over at one hundred degrees,60
and the drum is sounded up to five times,
for what reason?
Officers dress in black,
whereas within the palace gates they wear red single garments,
for what caution?
A belt is tightened round the waist,
a sward is carried on the right side,
and a blade is tied on the left,61
who established this dress?
A hook is adorned in the shoes,
and a cap is wore on the head,
what do thay stand for?
Officials live inside the city,
ride in a carriage when going out,
and sit to cope with documents.
Which emperor
first built the city?
Which artisan
invented carriages?
Where
was the place for first breeding horses?
And who
invented the charaters?62
It is difficult to know, who first built the city,
and where horses were first bred,
for it is too far away.
It is easy to know, who invented carriages,
and who invented characters,
hence they will certainly reply:
"Cāngxié invented the letters,
and Xīzhòng invented the carriage."
I refute:
"What inspired Cāngxié to invent the writing,
and what aroused Xīzhòng to invent the carriage?"
They do not know again.
These are what the officials ought to know,
but they do not know,
which is also for their faults of not extending their learning.
Now, the scholars do not study the ancient and the modern,
what they know is merely sticking to the knowledge of their teachers, 63
practizing the same paragraphs and sentences over and over,
explaining complicated words,
and distinguishing contradictory meanings.
The civil officials also do not know the principle of the officials,
what they are able to do is only investigating cases or inspecting matters,
writting letters or delivering documents,
and handling the situation skillfully.64
By measured, no one is complete,65
all are superficial and inadequate,
are one-sided and incomplete;
all have their shortcomings,
how can they blame one another?
The chapters of Chéng Cāi [the Weighing of Talents]and Liáng zhī[the Valuation of Wisdoms]
only have discussed the learning,
but have not yet spoken of the talents.
One possesses learning,
then he also has talents.
Civil officials show their talents in coping with business,
and scholars display their talents in their learning.
Some one inquired of Yáng Zǐyūn:
"There are strong men who can carry a huge tripod, or hold a decorative flag,
are there also such men in wisdom and virtue?
He replied:
"There are some one who surpass others one hundred times."
In fact, those who surpass others one hundred times in wisdome and virtue
equal those carring a huge tripod, or lifting a decorative flag.
Now strong men of great strength
are capable of carring a tripod or lifting a flag;
and scholars of great energy
can understand extensively or penetrate clearly.
Therefore understanding extensively or penetrating clearly
are the talents of scholars;
and raising a heavy or lifting a hard
are the talents of strong men.
The chapter Zǐcái [of Shàngshū]says:
"Powerful men help the king to open a path to wisdom,
and lead and reform the people."
This means that the wise are likewise powerful in properity and righteousness,
hence they can open a path to wisdom,
and can lead and reform the people.
Reforming people depends on properity and righteousness,
and properity and righteousness require writtings.
"Having still energy left after all exertions,
one may use it to study Classics."
Being able to study Classics
is a proof of one's possessing energy.
Some one may ask:
"Can a scholar who can explain one Classic
be regarded as a talent man?"
I would reply that
he is not a talent man.
When Páng Sháodū of Chénliú recommended some scholar for an office every time,
he always said:
"The talents of Mr. Wáng so-and-so equalled those of one hundred men."
The prefect was diffident of the talents of that man,
and did not reply.
Sháodū modified his previous remark, saying:
"I have not said enough about his talents,
Mr. Wáng so-and-so
surpass others a million times in talents."
The prefect said angrily:
"My close officer, you speak nonsense."
Shàodū said:
"Civil officials cannot understand a single word of a single Canon,
and cannot be familiar with one sentence spoken by a teacher.
Scholars, however, are able to explain a million paragraphs and phrases,
do not they surpass others a million times in talents?"
The prefect could give no answer.
Now, the remark of Shàodū
is true,
but still it is not quite to the point.
Why?
Because the scholars may be able to explain a million sentences,
but they could not know ancient and mordern events,
they just stick to the methods of their teachers;
although their explain words be manifold,
after all they cannot be regarded as a profound scholars.
The events which happened before the Shāng and Zhōu epchs
have been recorded in the Six Canons,
but these are what the scholars cannot explain.
The affairs of the Qín and Hàn time,
the scholars take no notice,
they lack of talents, hence cannot know.
The Zhōu drew lessons from the two[the Xià and the Shāng] dynasties,
and the Hàn drew lessons from the Zhōu and the Qín.
For the events that had happened since the Zhōu and the Qín,
scholars do not know;
the Hàn wished to learn,
but scholars are heplless.
In case scholars learn widely,
they may become cultured scholars.
The cultured scholars
have more talents than common scholars,
basing our judgement on Shàodū's words,
the talents of cultured scholars have surpassed others ten million.
Zēng Zǐ said:
"A learned man may not be without breadth of mind and vigorous endurance,
his burden is heavy and his course is long.
Perfect virtue is the burden which he considers it is his to sustain,
is it not heavy?
only with death does his course stop,
is it not long?"
Judging from this,
we learn that the aspiration of scholars
has been heavy alone;
and that the idea for which he is striving
has been board alone. ???
Their bodies carry a heavy burden up
to their last moments,
never tired and never decline,
only they have much energies.
Now, the bourden of Zēngzǐ consists in virture, and that of the scholars in learning,
what they carry are different,
but the weight is the same.
Now, the weight of a Dàn[60 kilogram]
may be lifted by one man,
but for the weight of more than ten Dàn,
even two men are incapable of carrying.
In the world, there are many men having strength to lift a Dàn,
but very few have the force to raise ten Dàn.
What the scholars carry
is not merely such weight as ten Dàn.
If the soil fertility is great,
plants and trees grow luxuriantly.
And the harvest of one acre
can match the product of five acres of average quality.
For planting field,
people know that the exuberant growth of grain is owing to the natural fertility of the soil;
but they don't know that aboundant leterary productions are the upshot of luxuriant talents,
which has been inconsistent with the logic of affairs.
In fact, the talent of cultured scholars surpasses that of common scholars,
how much more will they surpass that of civil officials?
Those who are able to recommend the wise and the learned
are regarded to have much talents by the common people.
But those who are able to recommend the wise and the learned
can also submit a written statement and present a report to their ruler,
and those who are able to submit a written statement and present a report to their ruler
are cultured scholars.
The cultured scholars must not necessarily be the common scholars,
only those being wise and able, and being able to write works are such kind of men.
Gǔ Zǐyún and Táng Zǐgāo submitted their memorials hundred times,
they had enough talents in writing,
spoke out what they think, cancealed nothing,
and were not short of literary talents,
only those who have ability and wisdom can do that.
Coufucius
was a man who had much talents in the Zhōu epoch.
He wrote the Chūnqiū,
and revised the Five Classics,
as for all secret books and abstruse writings,
there is no one that he did not inspected.
The bigger the mountains, the more clouds gather aroud them,
before the morning is over, Mount Tài has produced so much rain that it pours down on the whole empire.66
Thus,
the wise must have the talents like those clouds and rain,
hence they put forth more than thousands of tablets full of words,
they can be said to have great talents.
When people talk about strong men,
they use to extol Wūhuò.
Now Dǒng Zhòngshū and Yáng Zǐyún
are the Wūhuo in writing.
King Wǔ of Qín attempted with Mèng Yuè to lift a tripod, but he was not enough comptent(to do this),
broke his blood-vessel, and died.
If those who has little literary talents
express their innerments thoughs to Dǒng Zhòngshū and the like,???
they must be not enough competent (to do this),
and have such a unfortune as King Wǔ's broking his blood-vessel.
At the time of Wáng Mǎng,
the clauses of the chapters of the Five Canons were revised, every one was limited in two hundred thausand letters.
The doctor and disciple Guō1 Lù inspected the old explanation during the night,
and died under his candle.
His energy and mind could not bear the strain,
hence his arteries were broken, and his breath extinguished.
The son of Yán
had already surpassed Confucius in the course of virtue,
but he flagged and exhausted,
his hair turned white, and his teeth fell out.
Now, even with the talents of almost perfect,
Yán Yuān still had a misfortune of breaking down,
for the talents of Confucius was excellent,
but Yán Yuān had not enongh competence.
His talents and energy was not equal (with that of Confucius),
hence his minds could not catch up(with that of Confucius).
He forced himself to do the thing which was beyond his talents ten times or one hundred times,
spitting blood from his bosom,
losing his consciousness, and becoming disorder,
untill at last his breath ended.
To write boards of five rows of characters,
or to write memorials of ten rows of letters, ???
is hard for people who are short of talents in writing, ???
how could they combine sentences to make up paragrphs,
and reach the number of ten or hundred chapters?
Only those men (who can do this) possess a lot of talents.
That the waters of streams and rivers
flow rapidly, rush turbulently,
taking their long course through the ground,
without drying up,
is because that their sources are copious.
If one knows that the long course of streams and rivers
is due to their springs coming up from the ground are plentful,
but ignores that men who have written thousands of tablets
is because they have copious talents in their bosom,
he must be a confused man.
Thus, looked at, the hoof of a Ji兞a kind of horse that cau run thousand Lǐ one day]
is no different from the hoof of a common horse,
but when it gollops through the plain,
the sign that it can run a thausand Lǐ one day
can be found right away.
In fact the hoof of a horse and a human hand
are the same after all.
If one praises the hoof of a Jì,
but does not commend the hand of a man of letters,
he does not understand analogies.
Now, if one can find analogous facts through the judge of the strength of muscles, ???
then he can employ a strong man in letters,
and place him in the court.
Therefore a strong man in letters
is assisted by a strong governor,67
then he can make success through his talents.
If one possesses talents, but no assistant,
he will cause disaster for his talents.
How to prove this?
As to a big and ponderous thing,
only a strong man
can lift it.
As to a cart carrying heavy things,
only a strong ox
can draw it.
Thus when a cart carrying heavy things ascends a hill,
only a strong ox draw in front,
and a strong man push behind,
then it can ascend the height.
If the ox be feeble and the man worn out,
the heavy cart would roll back,
and move back into a ditch,
whcih will cause a danger of upsetting and smashing.
Cultured scholars cherish the principles of the former kings in their hearts,
and harbour the doctrines of a hundred[various] schools of thought,
they are hard to be pushed or pulled,
even more so than the weight of a heavy cart.
If those who recommond and push them
be weak and without energy,
they they retire and hide in rock caverns.
The Yellow River rises in the Mountain KūnLún,
and the Yángzǐ orignates from Mountain Mǐn,
their waterpowers are very great,
their surging streams
become more and more copious when they flow down,
but if they did not meet a wide banks and a low land,
they could never flow into the eastern sea.
If the banks were narrow, and the land high,
the waters of tributaries would burst a dyke,
and scatter in the wild land.
The learning of the cultured scholars
bears some resemblance to this.
Although the cultured scholars brim with literary talents,
but if they do not fall in with a strong governor to support and recommend him,
they also will be abandoned under their poor houses,
therefore how could they rise to the palace of the holy ruler,68
and discuss the affairs on government?
The light of a fire
does not shine, unless it be raised.
Now, here is a man
whose knowledge rises as high as a peak,
and whose virtue is like a mountain,
In spite of he has immense talents, he cannot raise himself,
and need others assistant, then he can raise,
but there is no one to assist him,
he takes his strong and great talents
and absconds in some remote alley of a village,
when he can get a apportunity to rise?
Ào and Yù
were the men of great strength in ancient time.
They could carry a thousand Jūn on their bodies,
and could tear off a horn or pull a hook straight with their hands,
however being called upon to lift themselves,
they could not detach themselves from the ground.
Those who are filled with wisdom and genius in their bosoms,
should stay in the king's palace.
A small stone being attached to a mountain,
the force of the mountain can hold it.
Among a sand dune,
the samll stone are so light
that it can also keep its position safely.
As regards a big stone,
it cannot be covered in sand and earth,
and cannot be hold by the mountain,
being placed on the edge of a preciptous cliff,
it is sure to tumble down between the valley.
Provided that a shcolar, heavy with wisdom,
comes acorss a governor with little talents,
and there is no such help like sand and earth to support him right or left,
although he is in an illustrous position,
the governor cannot keep him,
he will have the disaster of the big stone tumbling down.
Somebody cuts firewood on a mountain,
the light and small wood
can be tied together,
but as to the big trees
of more than ten spans,
they can neither be moved by pulling
nor be moved by pushing,
therefore they will be abandoned in the forest,
and people will collect the small wood which have been tied and return.
Basing our discussion on this point,
we know that the men of great talents
may resemble the big trees of over ten spans;
and that human force cannot raise or recommend them,
as the fuel-gatherer is incapable of pushing or dragging the big trees.
Confucius wandered round,
and there is no area where he could stay,
it was not because that his sagehood was not enlightened enough,
but since his grand principles were too difficult to be put into practice,
and nobody could make use of him.
Consequently Confucius
was the same species similar to an enormous tree on a mountain.
Duke Huán bringing about the confedation of the princes nine times[many times]
and re-adjusting the empire
depended on the talents of Guǎn Zhòng.
Guǎn Zhòng had his talents,
and Duke Huán could raise him,
this could be called strong.
Wú could not employ Zǐ Xū,
and Chǔ could not employ Qū Yuán,
the talents of the two men were great,
but the two sovereigns were unable to raise them.
If, when one has not enough strength to raise a thing,
one throws it on the ground and goes away,
then that is acceptable.
But sometimes out of anger,
one may cut it dilapidated with an axe,
this is the reason why Zǐ Xū and Qū Yuán encountered their misfortunes.
Fish in a pond
mutually devour each other,
they estimate that their mouths can hold,
then they swallow others;
If their mouth cannot hold,
they will get choked and cannot gulp down.
Therefore it is the same case that Shāng Yāng thrice persuaded Duke Xiào to accept his advices,
but solely his last proposal was accepted;
because that his two former advices were hard to practice,
and the last one was easy to carry out.
To observe the enlightened law of Guǎn Zhòng,
and to inspect the agriculture and military system of Shāng Yāng,
we know it is sure that these could not be taken by weak rulers.
In the time of the Six States,
when officers of good talents
went to Chǔ, the Chǔ became powerful,
when they left Qí, the Qí declined;
when they served for Zhào, the Zhào's territory was integrity,
and when they turned their back upon Wèi, the Wèi's territory was cut down.
The Hán State employed Shēn Bùhài,
and carried out his Sān Fú[three devices],
the army of other states dared not harass its frontiers
for about fifteen years.
(On the contrary,) the Hán State could not employ Hán Fēi,
and did not read his book,
hence the weapons were destroyed, the armies were defeated,
and the State was annexed by Qín.
In the Shāng and Zhōu epochs,
the events of revolutions came out in quick succession,
and the disasters of ruin happened one after another,
did they not wish to make a peace state in their hearts?
No. This was because that their energies were too weak, and the wisdoms were too little,
so that they could not accept best advices.
Thus, if a treadle-operated hammer is heavy,
one man's foot
cannot trample it;
and if a pile of stones is huge,
one man's hand
cannot push it.
Wise officers possess a merit for their strong talents,
and narrow-minded rulers have a demerit for their being unable to employ their wise officers.
In this case, they get along with each other,
as birds and fish play with each other.
If a Gàn Jiàng blade
is not thrusted by a man,
it cannot injure even water-plants and gourds;
and if a fine bamboo arrows
is not shot with a cross-bow,
even the Lǔ tissues cannot be pierced.
Not that such talents men like a Gàn Jiàng blade and a fine bamboo arrows are short of,
but without rulers like those who are able to thrust(a Gàn Jiàng blade) or shoot(a fine bamboo arrows).
Water-plants and gourds or the Lǔ silks cannot be cut or pierced,
how could we hope that the feat of cutting a flay or piercing an armour are achieved?
Therefore, with strength sufficient to draw a bow one may not pull a powerful balista.
Provided that the force of drawing the ballista needs five Dàn,
but it is pulled by a man with strength of three Dàn,
then his sinews are rent, and his bones broken,
and cannot draw.
Thus, if one's strength is not enough to draw a strong,
a catastrophe will ensue such as bending one's waist or breaking one's spine. 69
(In the same case,) if one's intelligent is not enough to employ wise men,
one will cause evil consequence of injuring his virtue or ruining his reputaion.
Those who discuss this kind of things do not admit that the wise men's talents are too great and their principles are too heavy,
so that sovereigns cannot use them;
but think that they are disabilities, hence they cannot raise themselves.
Those who recommend themselves are always block, and cannot show resilience,
and those who are inclined to parade cannot sold their goods, although the price is low.
By inspecting we know that all things used by man
require people to use them,
then their inherent values come out.
That a chisel can drive the wood
is because the hammer strikes it;
and that a spade can dig up the earth
is due to that one's feet presses down it.
The reason why all those sharp-edged tools
can cut and carve
is that they can be grasped by one's hands,
and can be pushed or pulled by one's forces.
Hán Xìn left Chǔ[the state of Xiàng Yǔ], and went into Hàn,
because Xiàng Yǔ could not make his position safe,
but Gāo Zǔ could keep his position stable.
Gāo Zǔ could appreciate his excellence,
and could make his body safe,
hence also could measure his talents
and discern his merits.
Fán (Kuài) and Lì (Shāng) had merits for their capturing cities and assaulting on the open battles,
but when Gāo Zǔ dispensed rewards according to merits,
he gave the first to Xiāo Hé.
He compared Xiāo Hé to a hunter,
and likened Fán (Kuài) and Lì (Shāng) to hunting dogs.
In fact Xiāo Hé only sat quietly,
while Fán (Kuài) and Lì (Shāng) were running in battlefields,
however, that the first reward was not bestowed on that runing person, but on those who had been siting quietly,
